reviewText:
7/10

A very nice story, with a nice plottwist.
The protagonist and two other main characters are nicely developed, they actually have something you can grab, something you can feel with.

The gameplay itself is rather linear and the only variety in fights appear, when you unlock new skills combos or face new enemies or boss battles.

The level design is very nice. It is apocalyptic and yet remains with a slight touch of blurry dream of a harmonic world. It´s also very interesting. I found myself trying to explore each corner of the levels I got into, the fact that there are several points of no-return in the game, kind of disappointed me.
And that you cannot visit all these interesting places, even though they seem to be accessable.

Outstanding cinematic feeling on the whole game, even when you´re not in cutscenes and excellent voice acting, as well as the soundtrack.

Overall, I would buy the game again, though it does not have a replayable value, as the story is the main carrier of the whole game. Once you know the story it becomes extremely repetitive. Similar to Bioshock.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Remember Me has a lot of things going for it. The story's premise, that memories are malleable -- readily extracted and remixed -- is interesting and full of possibility. The setting, Neo Paris (some 70 years in the future) is well-realized, full of colour and detail. For me, the environment art was the best thing about the game; I enjoyed looking in windows, walking around living spaces, and just generally exploring. The game features a strong soundtrack, and decent enough voice acting.

These positive qualities are tempered by significant weak elements, however. In particular, the core gameplay mechanic, third-person crowd fighting, is remarkably dull, and not enlivened by the ‘customizable’ combo system. There are four button combinations (increasing in length) that you can customize to ‘do’ different things (gain health, do damage, etc.), but once I had settled on combos I liked well enough, I rarely changed them. Fights quickly became repetitive and uninteresting, something to get past to move the plot forward. Furthermore, boss fights almost always end in quick-time events. The levels are entirely linear, and on-screen indicators tell you exactly where to go. What fun is Prince of Persia/Assassin's Creed style jumping and exploring when the game tells you exactly which platform is the next one in the sequence? There is one gameplay mechanic that was interesting, memory 'remixing', which requires you to 'scrub' through a memory and alter it in ways that change the outcome. Unfortunately, there are only a handful of these in the game.

In short, Remember Me has a lot of solid ideas, wrapped in beautiful scenery, but hampered by dull, repetitive and linear gameplay. This development team has a lot of promise, they just need to figure out how to execute better gameplay mechanics.

I would recommend this game, with reservations. On sale, for $20 or less, I would recommend it, at the very least to check out the environment and level art.

reviewText:
This game gripped me from the intro, the menu UI, the first level.
As stylish as it can get.

The gameplay is as linear as can be (a few collectables along the way take you a bit of the path, but not too much).
The combos are not really combos or quick-time events but just sequences of buttons.
The memory remixes are not really a game.

And I still love this and would love to see more of this! If you liked Binary Domain or any other (french) 3rd person action game, you will love this one.

reviewText:
So I finally took the plunge on this for $12.49 during Steam sale...and I was so happy I did.  I am having a blast so far with it.
Long story short, you forget your memory and now you're in an attempt to get it back.  The graphics are BEAUTIFUL, the music/sound is great, and the gameplay is fun for the most part.  You will be doing a lot of scaling of walls.  I don't mind the fighting even though you are pressing one of two buttons every time with a dodge here and there.  It is FUN.

This game is very linear; one path.  This would have been a perfect game to spin off of Dishonoured's open world gameplay and if they made a sequel, it would be in their best interest to go open world.

Thankfully, the eye candy makes it worth it.  An absolute steal at the price I got it at.

reviewText:
I was gonna wait until I finished the game to post this but I need the world to know how good Remember Me is.

+ The most diverse range of characters I've ever seen in a game
+ Beautiful soundtrack, especially the battle music cus it's influenced by your actions
+ Stunning open world
+ Customisable combos means fighting is way more than just spamming the same key
+ Story is amazing
+ Nillin's remix power is fun to play around with
+ No detail is spared, a lot of thought went into this game and I really appreciate the subtle extra hints (e.g. elevator scene in Episode 7)
+ Achievements are rly fun to work for
+ ROBOT STRIP CLUB

- The dramatic camera is annoying sometimes
- Battles are 50% dodging which gets tiring but the other battle features are cool, like the S Pressens, and they kinda make up for it

Overall +++++++ I love this game so much, I don't know where the bad reviews are coming from but it's so worth playing.

Remember you soon.

reviewText:
At times this seems like two different games, one is a smart midf*ck game (literally!) where you have to remix peoples memories to make them remember events differently to bend their will to your own ends. The other game is a straight up Batman style brawler, made way more complicated than it needed to be by you having to map abilities you unlock to the x, y, a or b buttons and then having to remember and try to pull off button combos in the right order and with the right timing.

The brawling sadly takes up most of the game, while remixing peoples memories you only get to do about 4 times in total throughout your journey through Neo Paris, which by the way made the game for me. This is one gorgeous and very cool looking city. It's sadly also incredibly linear while you are navigated through it while either climbing up buildings or fighting people.

Tonally it seems off as well, with your character and the story being overly serious but then undercut by these larger than life cartoonish villians you have to fight, which seemed totally out of place in this context, that was jarring for me.

The soundtrack was really awesome though, really memorable and hummable, in fact just get the soundtrack instead you'll enjoy it more :)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xOJ-Z357NxY&index=17&list=PLstXdGXEYegfDNZLqeogii9dYwM5V3Kya

I would recommend the game to anyone who likes walking around looking at cool architecture, the gameplay didn't really do it for me, but this is one of the few games where i think it's worth playing for the aesthetic over the actual gameplay.

reviewText:
It could have been 1 of the greatest games ever created...

I dont remember any other game that would get me on such an emotional rollercoaster,1 min i luv it only to hate it another.

Some parts of it are done so damn good,like visuals and overall design of characters and maps,even hairstyles its just magnificent!Music and sounds just breathtaking...but the gameplay is so so at best,its not bad its just nothing special.

The most interesting feature in the game which is memory mixing is used only 4 times in the game...why?

Why make it into platformer kinda game?Why not go stealth?The game asks for it on every corner...

And the fighting system...im ok with Batman/AC fighting system but here  you have no counter,its just strange decision since your being attacked by multiple enemies from multiple angles...

The whole game is like a genius(a real one) meets a failure and they decide to make a game together.

Another thing,with this engine,one of the best i encountered,everything looks beatiful and its well optimized but...you spent most of the game in sewers,slums and mostly dark areas where you can see ♥♥♥♥. Why?

Seems to me like a lot of ideas didnt get implemented into the final product and it breaks my heart cause i love cyberpunk,i love France,Nilin is beatiful and really cool heroine..just...ugh it could have been so much more.

To the verdict,with stuning visuals,designs,magnificent music,great story,new and fresh ideas but so so gameplay I give it :

8/10(it could have been 10)

I do recomend it,its worth your time and money.

reviewText:
This game took a beating on metacritic for certain gameplay and design elements, and while it took questionable approaches to some things, it wasn't afraid to stand up and be different. Some of them helped the game tremendously, and some took away from it, but at the end of the day Remember Me is very worth suffering through some annoyances of extremely linear level design, janky cutscenes and weird memory replay mechanics for a fantastic story with great characters in an undeniably gorgeous world.

Highlights
Remember Me includes incredibly gorgeous detailed environments and backdrops, and a very metropolitan, urbane feel to everything, a style which wouldn't be felt again until games like Deus Ex: Human Revolution

* Detailed NPCs add life to the environment. You'll often stop to eaves drop on NPCs engaging each other or having a conversation
* Interesting characters and especially very interesting bosses with personality which also help to add a dimension of challenge
* One of the best asses in video games

Mistakes
Remember Me stands up above many other games with some incredible design and production value, so it's painful and frustrating when something doesn't feel as well done as the other design elements. The extremely linear nature of the world, for example, feels like such a pain in the ♥♥♥ because of all the fantastic depth and beauty in everything else.

* The combat is unique and very good when understood, but the game does an awful job of explaining and guiding the player to use the system, and you can easily play through the entire game without ever fully coming to terms with the combat
* Some of the cut scene elements are un-skippable and just plain annoying at times

Recommendations
Remember Me clocks in at 10 hours of play time, and has a lower price point than most triple A titles, but at £22.99/27.99€/$29.99 it might be more than most should pay, considering the very dividing gameplay structure. When on sale, it's a real bargain, and worth the risk. It routinely goes -75% or more.

* The game was originally designed, under Sony, to play more like Assassin's Creed, and a much more open world and was then rolled back by EDGE due to the smaller story, and to help fit the story https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=68&v=4oFzeVYk7Is
* The Combo Lab Pack DLC adds a couple of extra fight moves which makes customizing your attacks mildly easier and more interesting but honestly adds nothing to the game overall for anyone other than committed fans.
* Remember Me was developed by DONTNOD Entertainment, who would later go on to create Life is Strange
* Plays a bit better with a controller, but a Keyboard plays fine too

http://store.steampowered.com/app/228300

reviewText:
7.5 / 10
Remember you later.

Overview
Remember Me is an action adventure game set set in the fictional city of Neo-Paris of 2084. You play as Nilin, a young, recently-turned-amnesiac woman who has clearly been having a pretty bad day. Nilin must regain her memories through hurdles presented both by the engrossing, eccentric environment that is the city and the evil entity that is the Memorize corporation.

Story
Being set in the future, the game naturally attempts to present a futuristic atmosphere and encompassment to the setting. Remember Me does a great job with this. Neo-Paris is a fascinating city saturated with surreal ideas like fancy heads-up holographic signage for nearly anything of even minor interest and, of course, the capitalization of the human memory (blame Memorize). The story holds up fairly well and, though sprinkled with a few cliché set pieces, has some very interesting twists and ideas that give it fair value. A heavy start that occasionally crawls to a furious finish.

Gameplay
When you are presented with the first combat scenario (the major gameplay aspect of the game), this is where Remember Me either pulls you in or whispers Uninstall me". The combat unfortunately feels a little stiff. It's not bad by any means (and I'll explain why) but it has its limitations. The entire combat experience feels somewhat grounded
date: which comes off as odd because the rest of the game suggests furiously-free
recommended: fluid mobility. Nilin hits fast and can leap around by somersaulting over enemy shoulders
hoursPlayed: but it feels ''on rails'' to some extent.\n\nStiff combat acrobatics aside
voteText: fighting in Remember Me is redeemed by the clever Pressens combo system. Through experience
helpfulPercent: Nilin acquires Pressens
votesHelpful: combat moves that can then be creatively placed into one of four combo chains found in the Combo Lab at any given moment. How you mix these up as you encounter different situations will greatly affect your performance. If you never change your combos
votesTotal: you will not progress through the game. Pressens come in three varieties: Power
votesFunny: Regen and Cooldown. Power hurts
commentsCount: Regen is obvious and Cooldown converts hits landed on bad guys into shaved time off of cooldowns for your S-Pressens
column16: unique moves that specifically target or damage particular enemy types. Some S-Pressens are a necessity to defeat certain enemy types
column17: and that's where your Pressen combos come in handy. You need to calculate (usually through trial and error) what Pressen sequences you'll want to assign to which of your combo chains depending on the enemies you face
column18:
or just go all-out Power and succumb to repetitive failure. I suggests learning about Pressens.

Technical
Remember Me did leave some bitter impressions on the technical side of things. Gorgeous visuals aside
column19: the game leaks memory very easily and performance issues become easily noticeable. After anywhere from 1 to 3 hours of gameplay
column20: the slick 60+ fps framerate would non-subtly dip to a variable 30-40fps (it only takes up to 30 minutes for this to occur when soaking in-game). A reboot of the title temporarily fixes the issue
column21: but you will need to repeat this process every few hours.\n\nThroughout the 26 hours of game time I have with Remember Me
column22: I've stumbled across 6 instances of very severe progression-breaking bugs that each left me needing to restart the entire chapter. I encountered only one of these during my first playthrough. During my follow-up playthrough
column23: knowing how to progress quickly
column24: I fell upon the other 5. Most of them seemed to be caused by simply interacting with or completing objectives too fast which is a shame
column25: epecially since Remember Me doesn't let you skip any cutscenes or cinematics. Some of these are long and they're quite abundant
column26: so when you're trying to speed through a second playthrough for some missed achievements
column27:
you're gonna do a lot of waiting.

The TL;DR
All in all
column28: Remember me is a solid 7.5 / 10 for me. Fair points lost for noticeable technical flaws of the PC port
column29: but a strong overall note thanks to the creative setting

column31: a soundtrack so fitting that it's practically transparent and a mostly-pleasant gameplay experience. Here's to a sequel that hopefully delivers even bigger."

reviewText: Remember Me is a cyberpunk wet dream.  The camera control is a little jarring at first, and I've got a feeling it's best played with a controller, but the story is so profoundly original, and the Neo-Parisian environments so awe-inspiringly beautiful, that you quickly become immersed in and engrossed with the game's universe.  Dontnod Entertainment have expressed an interest in developing a sequel.  If it happens, I just hope they will introduce RPG elements.  It's a fantastic game - particularly if this genre is your kind of thing - but it could easily have been so much more.

reviewText: After beating the game, I have realized how unexciting it was. While the combat is mildly entertaining, it is fairly repetitive. The introduction of new enemies is not a fresh challenge, but rather an annoying feature, like when enemies are invincible because they are powered by other enemies you must kill first, or turn invible during combat, or hurt you every time you peform damage even when attacking with a range attack. You do climb around like Assassin's Creed, but only through set paths, which again, I found to be more annoying than anything else, mainly due to the fact that you frequently fall and find yourself in trouble. Remixing memories is a puzzle, but once again, because they took awhile to figure out sometimes, I found them more frustrating than anything else.

reviewText: Remember Me is a very stylish futuristic action game.  The story is very intriguing and the gaming world looks fantastic.  You have special abilities to alter and steel other people’s memories in a world where memories are for sale and highly sought after.  The gameplay itself is a mismatch of fighting (with combos) and platforming climbing from one building to the next.  There are also some shooting and puzzle sections and even a few quick time events thrown in.  There is a bit of exploration for extras and power ups.  Gameplay wise its nothing fancy but everything is at least done competently with some variety, although you have probably done all of this stuff before in other games.  The unique part is sometimes you get to alter a person’s memoires to benefit your situation.  This part I found very interesting, but it only happens once in a while unfortunately.  Overall if you like action games with a futuristic setting then Remember Me is a solid choice.

If this is on sale, go on and grab it, you will enjoy the atmosphere. The idea of this game is just brilliant. But be aware of those bossfights and adapt the price accordingly. reviewText:
This is an exceptionally good game if you're into really believable sci-fi cities, technology, etc. The soundtrack is amazing, as is the visual design... Though sometimes the highly cinematic camera angles cause some issues. Even so, it's gorgeous. It also takes a lot of risks in terms of story, characters, mechanics, and most of the time all that pays off.

I could go on, but instead I'll get right to the point: There is absolutely a way to play this game that will help you enjoy it, and a way that will hinder you.

The combat often seems to drag and interrupt the flow of the game as a whole, and the voice acting is... Well, the English voices can be pretty hokey. Unless you're really looking for a challenge and/or really hate subtitles, do yourself a favour: Swallow your pride and play on an easier difficulty than you usually would, with french voices and subtitles in your preferred language. The easier combat lasts just long enough that's it's still fun but doesn't get in the way of the more substantial parts of the game, and the french voices VASTLY improve the tone & feel of the dialogue and cutscenes.

reviewText:
I've just finished the game. And it's well worth it. The number one feature is the environment/art style of the game, it's breath taking, and really had an impact on me, it immerses you in the game's narrative. The game sets a very plausible future of current technology/social trends.

Its' very cinematic, often the gameplay engine looks as good as prerendered. The charaters have character; the models/animation and voice acting are top notch. The music is well done and has a remixed/glitchy style that really fits the game.

The style it's lot's of cables, robots, computer servers, bright billboards, massive TVs, colorfully designed appliances, neon signs, grafittied concrete countered by Paris historical revolutionary statues etc... And Sensen everywhere from slums to Belleville.

reviewText: Without a doubt, this game has one of the best soundtracks in video game history. On that alone, I recommend a playthrough of the game. The visual design is also quite spectacular, and every time the camera shifts or pans into a vista, you can really see the detail in the game's environments. Unforunately, in the early part of the game, you spend a lot of time in some pretty boring and lackluster settings.\n\nCombat, in particular, the combo lab system, is a bit obtuse in the beginning. Once you realize the freedom you have in customizing a combo to give you extra damage, regen, or cooldown bonus, it's pretty simple to figure out the best order for your playstyle. The melee fighting behaves very similarly to the Batman Arkham games, where stringing combos and dodging at the !" prompts allows you to wipe the floor in most cases. The boss fights are particularly fun when the game throws a good mix of enemy types for you to handle all at once. They can get tricky
date: and I had the most fun in those scenarios.\n\nCertain cinematic moments (particularly a certain chase sequence) can leave you frustrated due to its trial-and-error nature. Thankfully
recommended: that kind of stuff does not happen often.\n\nThe story is enjoyable enough
hoursPlayed: particularly near the end
voteText: and if you're open to some cheesy sci-fi

reviewText:
I have discovered this game through Steam so I thought it was the proper place to write an review on where i founded the game ironic huh? I wasn't so sure if i was going purchase this game but I saw the Trailer, Read the Description and Look at the screenshots and it caught my attention right away. So i ended up buying at the risk of whether or not if i was going to seriously enjoy it.

It turns out my overally experience for this game was just ideally flawless I was amazing on how well scripted this game and how much my predicitions were all wrong Dontnod entertainment did an awesome job with an awesome storyline on their part. The Second thing I thought was amazing was just the action alone you had to think every second on when to encounter the leapers/guards and it was well challenged.

Another Thing that interest me was the customizations and the sensen powers who knew Niin (Sorry if i actually spelled her name wrong) would have the power to overdrive memories, control what happens and remix memories that just amazed me a lot and Dontnod Entertiament has an pretty interesting idea of the future but who knows what might happen.

I got this game when it was on the community sale during the Steam Winter Sale and Even if i did pay the full retail price i would still made the risk regardless. Its well worth your money and you can always go back and redo the story on a harder level.

reviewText:
Remember Me is in my eyes a totally underrated game if you're only a little bit into this type of game. It feels like a great cocktail of Mirror's Edge, Tomb Raider and Batman Arkham Series. The game takes place in the year 2084 in a world shaken by nature after the ice melted and a company invented a brain implant to manage your memories.

Pros:
* The visuals are astonishing. I really dug into the art style. Take a look at some of the screenshot and it will look even better in motion.
* The sound/music is awesome, too. Great compositions and dynamic mixes (e.g. for fights).
* The story! It great. You must play it to experience that on your own. Made me think what's going on in my head once or twice. ;-)
* The love for details. I felt really impressed on how much work they invested into (small) details. Floating signs telling you the store is closed, but the website is online or to watch your step close to an edge, just make the world to feel complete. The memos you can find, will tell you stuff like details about the history of the world.
* Memory Remixs: During the game you have to manipulate a couple of memories which is done by scrolling" the memory forward and backward and change simple things like the position of a chair which may make the scene to come to a whole different ending.

OKs:
* Fights are like Batman
date: but not that fluid. You've got lots of enemies and mixed up types. So you have to manage your techniques and modify your combos to match new challenges. During fights you bulld up focus which allows you to trigger special moves you're granted through the story.\n* Traversing the linear levels is basically straightforward. The climb/jump/shimmy stuff feels like Tomb Raider
recommended: although there's always a marker pointing where to go. All over the level are hidden powerups/memos so you have to look left and right.\n* There are quick time events in the boss fights. They may feel cool
hoursPlayed:
but I don't like them when they force me to repeat stupid stuff (like part of the fight before) when I press the wrong button.

Contras:
* I had some control issues (keyboard+mouse) with an action scene where you're chased by a madman in an armed helicopter. Dunno if they were not precise enough or if it was just me.
* One boss fight is somehow plain stupid as its extremly repetitive. It took some tries to get the basics and then it was not really fun. All other bosses felt much better designed.

Overall: You have to play it yourself!"

reviewText:
Remember Me is fantastic work.  First of all, if you think MP is some kind of Holy Grail of gaming, or that 'Collectibles' are a modern trend that is core to gaming, then steer clear of Remember Me.  It's not for you.  This has been made by a team of artists and designers who had a big vision for a game and saw through a pretty good contender for a long-lasting favourite.

This game can be over fairly quickly if you rush the lot.  Don't - I like a game that lets me walk rather than run.  Check out the grand amazing vistas, the grime of the grungier parts of town, look for your journal entries, get absorbed, and this is far longer than most attempts at a SP campaign in cinematic game offerings at the moment.  The repeating levels was a minor 'hmmm' however there is a good reason for each revisit and reinforces the impact of your actions in the story-line.  This said, it felt a little restricted to too few areas for such a big city, never mind the injured world itself.  I came across a couple of bugs where the game hadn't registered a combat or action success and I had to restart the last checkpoint (minutes spend repeating myself, but there were just minutes.)  Combat threatens to become repetitive however that's avoided if you play as they mean you to - tactically, fluidly, and adapting.

The soundtrack has been crafted with the game themes in mind.  The acting is some of the best I've heard in a game in ages, particularly Nilin, whose actress does help keep you in the mood and pace of the scene.  On this note, atmosphere is rich, as is the world you're running in - again, you can tell how much effort has gone into this project when close attention as been paid to architecture on varying levels of modern on top of classic, with plenty of evidence of life.

The game's pace keeps you continually upgrading via a system of memory recollection (which basically works like experience). Apparently the combat has come under fire from some reviewers but I don't see the problem - you are clearly given the approach to take with different enemies, and if you forgot, check the Journal.  The game allows up to four combo sequences into which you can place hits and kicks of different properties.  You customise your combos to give you what you need - timing your combos is key to success, and for me, this works.  It's a very accessible tactical approach to avoid mindless button mashing. The other aspect of the game which I really liked was the memory remixing.  This isn't an idea milked to death, and sees you rewinding and pausing memories, altering details to change the outcome, and the target's motivations.  It's very linear, and I was even a little frustrated when certain obstacles that the acrobatic Nillin could clearly get over acted as invisible walls, or insurmountable set pieces (I do like to climb on stuff).

To finish off, back to the storyline - it went to places I didn't anticipate and in the end I was treated to an excellent bit of sci-fi, with a back story of decent depth if you care to look for it.  And you should, because the origin of this dystopia helps understanding it all.  The writing is on top form - some of the baddies and tough goodies are pretty standard but the story behind the world is well thought through.  The dystopia rose from a humanitarian ideal, brought down by greed, with a broken well of regret and pain at its core.  You'll be forced to take actions you question.  Is it right to enslave public menaces and monsters?  Is it right to change who a person is for a greater good? etc.  The plot delves deep into the important characters (including Nillin of course) and by the end, the world has changed.

This game could have been incredible, it could have been a lot more, but there's still enough to appreciate.

Easy test now: If you're still reading, this is a game you shouldn't miss.

reviewText: What a thrilling ride this game has turned out to be.  The storyline ins intriguing and sophisticated.  There are no guns in this game its all memory mind weapons and street fighter light action combat.  Once you get familiarized with how the combat works it just blows you away.  There is nothing so satisfying as completing a five point combo and seeing the powerful effects it has on your enemies.  The game environment is so beautiful and cyberpunk this includes Nilin the protagonist.  My one and only gripe is the world is so detailed and beautiful it compels you to explore it but the game story is linear so you can't deviate too far.  Other than this little, tiny, hiccup it is a genuine cyberpunk rollercoaster.  I give it a 9/10.

reviewText:
This game was quite something. I'm personally a fan with the whole topic of mind experiments and to what extend humanity can reach for a new world development, not to mention this game made it look in a way I didn't really though of: a dystopia. Gameplay has its regular fightning mechanics and the twist is that you can configure your own combos from specific animations, you can do any configuration but at some point you will need to make a standard build which most likely won't be visually appretizing, but hey, it works efficiently! Soundtrack is very well made (fan of orchestral music) and gives this game a great sci-fi aspect.

Gameplay 9/10
Graphics 9/10
Story 8/10
Soundtrack 9.5/10

A game with linear gameplay, interesting combat mechanics, great story and an amazing soundtrack. Highly recommended for story loving gamers that are looking for a challenge in the fighting genre.

reviewText:
'Remember Me' es un juego impecable, divertido y facil de jugar con tu gamepad. Su disenyo artistico es asombroso, cuidando el minimo detalle de lo que aparece en pantalla, mostrando un Paris de 2084 con lineas futuristas combinadas a la perfeccion con la arquitectura tan caracteristica de esta ciudad. Es arte en movimiento, una experiencia audiovisual maravillosa sin duda alguna.
En este juego tendras accion a montones; robots y enemigos varios en grandes cantidades para poner a prueba tus habilidades en combate, en el devenir de su interesante argumento. Y es que aqui no hay nada dejado al azar.  Cada minuto, cada esquina, cada nota de su excelente banda sonora, cada enemigo a batir...ofrece una experiencia maravillosa al jugador, provocando que permanezcas pegado a la silla durante toda la partida, sin apenas parpadear por miedo a perderte el mas minimo detalle. Porque con 'Remember Me' lamentaras tener que dejar de jugar. Su ambiente te envuelve y embelesa como lo haria la mejor de tus experiencias en la vida real.

Como detalle curioso del juego, me gustaria comentar un exquisito guinyo de los desarrolladores del juego hacia esa pelicula de culto como es Desafio Total, llamando Dr. Quaid a uno de los principales personajes de la historia. Un tipo que se dedica a 'hurgar' en la memoria de la gente. Simplemente sublime.

Gracias, 'Remember Me'.

Como dicen en el juego...'I will remember you soon'.

reviewText:
Great, unique story in an atmospheric cyberpunk setting paired with a fluid combat system that incorporates (partially) customizable combos, Tomb Raider style platforming and a few puzzles.
The difficulty isn't that high,so it's perfect for a few relaxing evenings spent with beating the crap out of stuff while enjoying a good story.
If you liked Deus Ex and the combat in the Batman Arkham games / Spiderman 2 (the good one for consoles) this game is definitely worth picking up.
Xbox 360 controller strongly recommended.

reviewText: This is a great game. I had a blast playing it. I play 99% of my games with keyboard and mouse, but I don’t recommend it with this game. In fact when I switched to my Xbox controller for PC the game mechanics and combat just worked 100% better. The game has cool features I don’t remember encountering in other games. You can build your own combos with certain bonuses in them such as healing, or special ability cool down decreaser. The enemies are fun each type you have to find the right tactic and/or combo to counter them. This keeps the fights interesting throughout the game. There is also a feature in the game where you can hack someone’s brain and change their memories by altering small things and see how it plays out until you get the result you are looking for. The story is strong and a little emotional. I got this game on sale around 20 bucks and I think that it’s a fair price. It took around 12 hours to complete. After you are done you can jump to different levels to complete achievements you may have missed. Graphically the game is awesome; very detailed and polished. I rate this 89/100.\n\nThe city could have been a little more open and I wish I could have gotten a little more detailed with the combos.

reviewText:
Pros:
Has Steam Achievements and badge trading cards.
Comparable to the Batman games.
Great graphics, maps, voiceovers, plot, story, action.

Cons:
There is some problems with the remix sequences, but doable.
Can use gamepad for better fighting but harder to move through maps.
Keyboard and mouse is harder for combat but helps on moving through maps.
Is sort of buggy, but playable.
Need better instructions and tutorial.
The automatic camera system is terrible though, you can use something to move the camera view.
There is no clear detailed stats on what each individual skill does.
Gameplay is Ok, but has annoying QTE parts in the bossfights.

Be a great game for those that like melee fighting games and platformers.
Buy When on Sale.

Remember Me is a Wall crawling and melee combat game set in 2084 Neo Paris.
Very Cyberpunk environment.  Very challenging even on easy mode.  You will need to learn to use combat moves correctly to make it to end.  Bosses and combat gets progressively harder, with larger groups of attackers at times.

Main Character is great at free climbing and jumping and the path has plenty of: ledges, pipes, hand holds, ladders, jumps, leaps, drops, dangerous areas and rides on objects.  MC is a melee fighter, she runs into preprogramed fights a lot along her linear path.  There is health stations and other pickups hidden along the route and the auto save is helpful.  The path is shown by arrows on the Augmented Reality viewer, but hard to see the path sometimes.  The automatic camera system is terrible though, you can use something to move the camera view.

MC has several combo attacks choices LMB is a 3 hit combo, RMB is 6 hit combo, and 8 hit combo and you have other modes that you can activate after gathering focus and has cooldowns.  The combo attack skills are unlocked and can be placed in any order, but there is no clear detailed stats on what each individual skill does.
MC also can steal and manipulate memories, so there are memory remix puzzles and path guides.


For more info:

reviewText:
Amazingly underrated game with one of the most original worlds in recent times. I saw some of its concept art floating around the internet before finding out what game it belonged to, and those pieces, while great, don't do that game any justice when you actually see the game in motion. Every piece of art has been translated over into the game world flawlessly.

The story is reminiscent of creative works such as Ghost in the Shell, Blade Runner, Total Recall, and the such, which I'm sure without a doubt that those works had a huge influence on its narrative, and its very telling in its aesthetic that it definitely took influence from those. The combat system is kind of like the rythmic sort of combat that's become the norm in a lot of action games, such as the Batman Arkham series of games, or for example Assassin's Creed. The game also allows you to build your own combos, with a variety of different effects that you can unlock and choose from, in an a la carte type customization.

While not that long of a game, I do think it is a very engrossing one, although my one constant complaint that I would have with this game is that the camera isn't the greatest, in fact it can be pretty frustrating to deal with sometimes, but it's really not that much of a hassle once you get used to it.

I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for an action game, something with an original story, and with an interesting world. It's a shame that this didn't get much exposure, or money, so I kind of doubt that it'll get a sequel. Which is a disappointment, since original games like this are few and far in between in a modern market saturated with sequels or adaptations of already existing IP's,

reviewText:
I bought the retail version of the game when it came out, admittedly taken by its visuals and its concept but unsure if it would be worth the money I paid.  I am not too keen on using controllers when I play games so unfortunately I played Remember Me a little bit then shelved it. Recently playing another Capcom game with a similar concept led me to dust Remember Me off and replay it. So here is my belated thoughts of the game:

I'm going to start with its combat because there is so little to be said about it. If you have played games such as the Batman Arkham series and do not mind the combo building style of combat and platforming, then Remember Me will not disappoint you, however if combat like this is not your cup of tea and you are not fan of hanging from high buildings, then you will be very frustrated while playing Remember Me (especially on the hardest difficulty).

On the other hand, if you are not too fussed about the combat and are more interested in a very well told story, amazing art work coming to life with perfectly executed graphical design, as well as interesting characters and enemies, then this is a must-play for you. Not to mention, the soundtrack is quite good and the voice-over acting is flawless. It was also nice to play a female protoganist that was desinged very well with a realistic attitude and body posture, and not running around in bikinis.

The setting is in 2084 Neo-Paris. The details in the environment, characters, and enemies are amazing. I recommend you try and find all the collectibles (as some of them are very well hidden and will take you to every nook and cranny). The audio is flawless, from the music and the enviornmental sound to the voice acting, especially the voice acting which is very professionally done - it definately puts the player in the right mood.

Despite of the unfortunate events the protoganist goes through, her desperation is just, without sounding needy. The rest of the voice acting is also perfect, as it gives you the correct emotions towards the other characters, (such as liking or disliking them, getting annoyed by them or feeling sympathy for them). The physique of the character in my opinion stands out - recently the protogonists in video games have been on the extreme side of appearances (especially females with unrealistic body shapes that in the real world would make it impossible to do the things they do in games). However in this one, the protognist (Nilin) is designed perfectly to play the role of the fast, agile and lean heroine without going over the board and shadowing her feminity.

The most important thing that captured me about this game was the main concept of the game, playing with people's memories. I found it quite unique and I don't think I came across anything like this before in a game. It was very refreshing.


(TL;DR Version) I highly recommend this game to players who are looking for story-rich, beautifully designed game with Batman Arkham series style of gameplay, set in Neo-Paris with a unique concept.

reviewText:
Remember me is a sci-fi cyberpunk styled, futuristic action game.

The story is the main positive feature of this game, with some awesome ideas and i believe it  would actually make a pretty good movie.
The voice acting is also very good and it did its part in keeping me immersed in the game.

Graphically Remember Me is also great with some really nice envoironments and character models.

That being said the weakest point of the game would be the gameplay, it is servicable and it is not poor by any means.
But it can get a bit repetitive at some points and it also has some pretty cool puzzle solving elements such as memory remixing that are criminally under used.

If you enjoy games with great futuristic cyber punk storylines like I do then Remember Me is highly recommended.
Just don't go in expecting Devil May Cry levels of combat gameplay.

reviewText:
Abolutely recommended.
The visuals, gameplay and story is just perfect for me. Mix up Prince of Persia (combat, climbing) Resident Evil (bosses, quick-time events) and Mirror's Edge (sci-fi environment) with some mind-blowing memory manipulation and you get Remember Me.

I really like this game.

reviewText:
Remember Me was, well.. memerable.  From the voice acting to the cinematography.  Simply a beautiful game.

Visual/audio 90/100.

The fighting/action and mechanics were easy to master and not very hard or complicated.  There were a few times where it bugged out just a bit. Some Boss battles required you to learn timing and triggers and became a little predictable.  Over all 75/100.

Story was linear but well done with a few suprises thrown in to keep you involved. 80/100.

A nice feature of the game was reminicent of Mirrors Edge.

I kept wanting to yell Parkour after jumping from ledge to ledge to overhang.  Parkour!

All-in-All I would give it an 80/100.  I would recommend Remember Me for someone looking to be told a story and enjoy a visual experience.

reviewText:
Remember you soon!
That is what the game says, and that is what I would say to the game. No doubt, you have to play Remember me.
You ask why? Because it is one of the most original games I've ever played. Interesting story, excellent game art, stunning soundtrack performed by an orchestra, unique level design. Even the starting menu looks great. But, unfortunately, this game is not perfect. The reason of this is not a bad gameplay. Even though the combat system was critiicized by lots of gamers, for me, it seems OK. Looked a bit complicated at first, but after some time I got used to it and, actually, got fun from gme fights.
So, my main complain about this game - bad face animation. Good game art hides most of the graphic flaws, but when it comes to looking at some character's face closely, while one is talking to somebody - all face animation problems become visible. Often face emotions just do not combine with a nice voice acting, spoiling impression about the game.
Another complain is not being able to go back after some checkpoints. Oftenly I missed some secrets just because chose the wrong door that lead me to the next story episode.
But, in spite of all, I liked Remember me. And I will definitely play this remarkable game again.
My personal rating for it - 8/10.

reviewText: This is absolutely worth playing if you're into sci-fi at all, especially the kind of near-future sci-fi that deals with new technologies that reveal something about the human condition, a la Deus Ex: HR. This is unfortunately not nearly as well-written or engaging as Deus Ex, but it does present a similar sort of experience (and with much better graphics. Worse music though). Remember Me runs really well too, and plays great-- the fighting is actually really fun despite the terrible lack of enemy variety, and the ability to nimbly leap over enemies as you're comboing them really makes you feel like you're controlling a skilled fighter (serioulsy, the nimbleness is off the hook here, and a nice departure from the usual cover-based face-shooting of Every Other Action Game Ever). The main character Nilin is another reason to play-- the character model is really a nice design, and i love the way she gets all out of breath after running a lot and the way she kind of looks around while  she's walking-- these are great details that really add to you caring about her. Hell, play it just because you get to play as a cool biracial French woman with a sweet haircut instead of the usual Generic Beefcake White Dude-- an extremely refreshing departure on this count as well (and if it bothers you that everyone is speaking English in a game set in freaking Paris, there's actually the option to switch the audio to French with English subtitles, so if you're a great big hipster like me and want it to seem more authentic then you're in luck).\n\nShort version: very nice looking and never frustratingly difficult, and although the story is basically a Luc Besson movie stretched over ten hours, it does at least broach on an interesting subject and also makes you care about the character and what happens to her. Definitely a solid purchase if you're into Sci-Fi, though if you're not you can probably skip it unless, again, you want the rare experience of playing a game where the character isn't like the character in every other game out there.

recommended: Remember Me is worth your time.\n\nOn the whole, an underrated game that deserves more love than it's gotten.

reviewText: What makes this game great is the mix of beautiful graphics, the interesting female protagonist of color, the combat system, the thrilling story and the adrenalizing soundtrack. It surely isn't the greatest video game ever created but sadly immensely underrated; it offers so much new since you're not in your generic white American town and the plot actually isn't already overused. While the main story only takes about 10 hours to finish and there are no side missions, it has a great replay worth since you can create completely different fighting combinations which, especially on memory hunter mode, give the game a whole new level of difficulty.\nPlease give this game a try, if you're not willing to spend 30 bucks wait for the steam sales when it drops down to 6, and immerse yourself in the beautiful world of Neo Paris.

reviewText:
Gameplay:  Good.  The combat is easy to pick up.  The combo system is solid.  There's a combo system that is customizable and easy to pick up.  The special abilities are useful, and executing combos rewards you by letting you use more special abilities.  The remixes are neat and unique.  There are a few puzzles, and they are quite easy and logical.

Graphics:  Great.  This game is gorgeous.  There world is lovingly created, and it shows.  Neo Paris looks great, and the characters look amazing.

Plot:  Great.  This is one of the few games where the plot is very original.  The plot moves along quite nicely, with just enough mystery to keep you wanting to know more.  There are some nice twists along the way.   The plot, and world envisioned here is good enough to be a good movie.

Cons:  Some of the fights, you're not quite sure what to do.  The game eventually gives you some hints on what to do if it thinks you're stuck.  Overall a very minor quibble.

reviewText:
I really liked this game and dont see why so many people hate on it. The remix scenes were fun and i felt they balanced them well, they didnt include so many that you get sick of them and the ones they did fit into the story very well.
The combat also felt very good to me and the balance of brawling and platforming felt really good too. I think a lot of people are not playing into the game very far or they would see all the platforming and understand this isnt just a blind brawler.

ive played all the batman games and while they are great they feel like button mashing fests if you play them that way. yes you can be thoughtfull and fight with strategy but its totally possible to button mash at anytime and succeed. while inthis game remember me you cannot just button mash blindy, you have to remember the combos you make and change them often to take advantage of the games potential. if you just mash X you will die quick esp the further you get into the game. i liked the idea of being able to heal with certain successful strikes and combos. it made me look forward to unlocking longer combos and strikes. its also the only way to beat certain enemies later in the game that mirror the damage you give to them back at you. if you dont use enough heal strikes you kill yourself. also the powers felt good and the cooldown system worked well. they have 1-2 min cooldowns (maybe more for some) but if you make use of the combo and strikes that shorten cooldown you cut a lot of time out of it and make them available much sooner. This all relies on the correct use of the combat and well placed strikes within the combo chain to be successfull.

i finished the game in toughly 20 hours. I didnt try to go fast but I didnt try to go slow or 100% it either, i just enjoyed it and played.

reviewText:
I'll be the first to admit that this is an odd action adventure game. The combat relies on the execution of well-timed combos. Combos which you can and must define yourself. An interesting idea that breaks with usual genre conventions, but ends up feeling not really satisfying. Maybe because this mechanic forces you to perform accurately timed button presses all the time, which keeps the player from truly enjoying some sort of flow of combat.

Another quite interesting aspect is the ability to remix memories. Basically you have to manipulate an ingame cutscene, which you can forward and rewind, to ultimately change the outcome to the one you desire. From a purely gameplay perspective this is indeed questionable, but it's an interesting variation of storytelling and does build atmosphere. You don't get to do this often during the game though.

The rest of the gameplay mainly consists of horribly stilted platforming, trivial puzzles and walking around a scrictly linear path. Doesn't sound too exciting overall. The reason why I still immensly enjoyed Remember Me lies in the unusual science fiction scenario that manages to build an immersive atmosphere. Certainly not for everyone!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Remember Me is one of the best games ever made. It's top notch story, artwork and graphics that will leave you stunned, and great musical score makes this game something you 'll never want to forget. The only downside is the first few levels leave the combat a little meh(~2 Hours).

The Story:

Without spoiling anything Remember Me is a game where you think you know what's going to happen. When you finally play it you'll see that there is even more then you thought. The story in this game is one of the best stories ever told in a Big Budget released titles. The world feels real and the story plays off this amazingly constructed world perfectly. It may even make you rethink how you view your own memories.

The Graphic/Artwork:

The detail in this game is above any other I've seen. Little robot float by with signs showing you the specials of places to eat or shops. The floating text  of the signs are at the perfect depth in order to feel as if they are realistically placed. Dirty places feel dirty and not over done just like clean places feel just the right amount of clean. Nothing is over done and the detail is so perfect it's insane to think about. You really feel as if you are part of the world. The 3D is also very good.

The Sound/Music:

The Musical score in this game is perfect as well. It combines classic big orchestra sound with corrupt technology sounds in the perfect manner. Sound is one of my favorite things in a game so even if this styles sounds crazy even at first I didn't believe how well it sounded.

The voice acting in the game is great only maybe 3 lines in the game feel out of place. Each actor adds emotion to their character and draws you into the story and scene. The combat sounds can get a little repetitive though because the enemy are always saying the same one liner all the time. Nothing that can't be over look.

The combat noises and ambient sounds are also really well done. You heard ADs over a PA system about a product in the world or what just happened in the news. Robots talk about protocol for the area or you just hear people talking in the streets.  You can hear the distant sounds of computers running around a corner or a leaper hiding the shadows. The combat noise of punches landing and other abilities hitting are fine as well. Things sound satisfying when they land and never out of place.

The Gameplay:

The gameplay is one of the weakest parts of Remember Me at the start of the game. You don't have many abilities, pressens, or combos and it can feel as if you are just spamming the one or two combos you do have in order to just get through. When you finally unlock everything the style of combat you do is almost an art of itself. It flows so well and looks very good. At the beginning of the game it can seem that the combat is down right bad but give it time it gets really fun.

The platforming in Remember Me in very linear as the game is pretty much 95% linear. There are a few places you can go in order to find collectibles but other then that it's pretty much follow this path. The platforming is pretty easy and really just something you do in order to find the solutions to puzzle as it's pretty hard to fail these sections. Overall the platforming is neither good nor bad it's pretty ok.


All in all if you are looking to pick up Remember Me I strongly suggest you do. I played it the whole way through in Nvidia 3D and it was great. I recommend using a controller so you can lean back and enjoy this amazing game.

By far the Must Play Game of 2013.

reviewText: I liked Remember Me. The style of this game is fantastic. Its vision of 70 years in the future was interesting and believable with a lot of fancy new tech around, but not too far technologically advanced. Frequently it was fun to stop and check out the scenery. There are a lot of nice little touches that add a lot of detail and flesh this world. There is some real stunning visuals in this game. Unfortunately, there are a few texture and lighting problems that make some areas just overall look crappy and don't sparkle like most of the rest of the game does. There's far too much time spent in sewers and drab dark places. Also, the world does feel empty as there aren't a lot of NPCs to fill out the levels to make it feel alive. Honestly, the story was mediocre, but not terrible. And the actual format of the game has been done so many times before. Travel to a big room and punch up a bunch of dudes and then continue on until the next fighting room is reached. The fighting wasn't anything special, but I did enjoy it. The combo system made for some interesting fights that reminded me a lot of the Batman series. The story involves a chilling future scenario where memories are bought and sold like commodities and memories can be rewritten at will by jacking into peoples brains. The expression 'Remember Me' does have a significance to the story, but I kept getting the feeling the makers weren't exactly confident in the game they were making and they kept repeating the phrase in the game so people will remember to tell their friends about the fun time they had playing through this game. The game is fairly easy. There were only a couple of difficult boss battles. It took just over 12 hours to complete the game. I liked this new mechanic where someone's memory would play out on screen and as it progresses key details can be changed to alter the memory in sometimes insignificant, sometimes profound ways. It was fun trying different combos to see how the memory changes in sometimes wildly different ways. Tweaking to get things to play out just right. This game does kind of remind me of a kinder, gentler take on the Resident Evil series. Instead of shooting missiles at genetic mutant freaks and driving down zombies, you're punching security guards. And instead of blood and monster puss stained walls, everything is covered in neon. But the RE vibe is definitely there. It's a fun game and I recommend it.

reviewText:
Stability: 7/10
Story: 9/10
Grapics: 8/10
Music: 7/10
Gameplay: 5/10
Replayability: 6/10
Value: 7/10

This game is a pleasure to play. The story is excellent and very original, the soundtrack is beautiful and the visuals are stunning (as if I'd expect anything less from MTG's Aleksi Briclot). I only have two issues with this game. First, there are several bugs which can prevent you from finishing a chapter (just reload to fix them). Second, and perhaps more importantly, the combat is awful. Not quite bad enough to stop me from playing, but bad enough that it really took away from the overall enjoyability of the game. However, because of all the other wonderful characteristics, I'd definately recommend this game. If you're on the fence, wait for a sale, and buy it then. But definately buy it!

reviewText:
Remember Me never quite meets it's full potential but it's still a robust experience overall.
For starters, it's one of the most visually striking games I've ever played. The graphics and art direction are absolutely phenomenal. I'd almost solely recommend this game on the strength of it's visuals, it's that good.
The game has a very uneven story though it's bursting with originality. The writing is smart enough to ask to right kind of questions and there are some truly memorable moments in the 9 chapters that comprise the story.
Nilin, who already stands out from most video game protagonists by being a woman of colour, is written with the right balance of emotion and toughness. She feels vulnerable but is always capable of getting the job done. In between each chapter Nilin monologues about what's she done and how she feels; there are some genuinely interesting moments of pathos for her that flesh out her personality. She's much more interesting that other characters in these types of games such as Kratos or Dante.
Remember Me's biggest fault is the gameplay. This is a character action game with a total of 5 combos. Changing what your combos do is a good idea in theory and having multiple enemy types helps but it doesn't change that you essentially are pushing the same combination of buttons for the entire game. This is going to be a problem for many people, especially if you're looking for a challenging experience. The combat doesn't nearly have as much depth as competing games in the same genre.
If you're new to the action genre, or you want an adequate action game with a good story, then I recommend Remember Me. If you want a highly polished action game, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
This game is surprisingly amazing.
I was expecting something quite mediocre, but what I got was a really good game. In it's genre, I would even say it's the best.
The graphics are alright. The gameplay may sometimes be repetitive, but still fun as hell because it's a slasher and murdering hordes of enemies with majestic (and they are) combos just can't be boring. Speaking of combos, you can build your own, which I don't think I've ever seen in any game before.
Before the release, they promoted this memory manipulation feature, and some people might have been fooled by it. There are only several times when you do that. And it's not gameplay, it's story. It's extremely linear. It's not bad, just not that I thought it would be.
Speaking of story, it was awesome. Several nice plot twists and interesting characters. Especially the protagonist.
OST also fits fights perfectly with all the glitchy stuff.
So, yes, it is really good. A gem, that was shamefully lost in that pile of garbage that people call gamedev of 2013"."

reviewText: For some reason I find this one of the best games I've ever played. Perhaps it's the interesting and well written story. Or the pretty much flawless motion capture, voice acting or dialog? Could be that the futuristic Paris is one of the must stylish and well imagined sci-fi settings I've seen. Possibly the slick game elements of the memory re-mixing and building of the fighting combinations. But perhaps the most probable reason is that the game made me think a lot. Not only about the game aspects, but mostly about the story and its implications.\n\nAnyway, it is despite being quite a linear game one of the most enjoyable solo gaming experiences I've had in many many years. I will make sure to keep my eyes open for anything else made by the same artists.

reviewText:
(Review is completely subjective and based on my own experiences, not others.)
(I may spoil gameplay mechanics, but I won't spoil the story/key facts)

TL:DR
Storyline/Entertainment/Gameplay 9/10
Combat 6.5/10
Environment 10/10
Controls 8/10
Replayability 2/10

Overall: 8 - 7.5 /10 - Would recommend to those who are more casual gamers, not intense action shooters.

Details:
I saw this game while browsing the steam store page. Trailers seemed awesome so, *click, buy*. When you enter the game you are immediatly immersed with backstory and introduced to the main character, Nilin. While i won't spoil any of the storyline, I'll overview the general way in which things were layed out. The story is all about discovering Nilin's past while rebelling against the forces controlling Neo-Paris. Where she is, why she is here, what happened to get her in this situation?

Storyline/Entertainment/Gameplay:
This game, to me atleast, is much more a story with interact-able content than a point-and-click adventure. Im not saying that the game was intense on cut-scenes (it wasn't, but ill address this later), but more that each episode of the game is linear (not open world) and would lock doors behind you, preventing exploration backwards in the level. There was never a moment where I was bored during this playthrough, enjoying every little event which happened. Every turn was new and new gameplay mechanics were added continually as you progressed. Although when some mechanics are added, there is no tutorial. So you have to work it out on the fly. The story is spread out along 7 or so episodes, each progressing on the previous to tell the story of the rapidly-evolving state of Neo-Paris and Nilin.

Combat:
To be blunt, I felt the combat was clunky, but innovative. You're rewarded for doing combos by getting a rockin' soundtrack playing in the background. This however is taken away when you take just one hit. Combos are built off of 'nodes' and vary in effect. The first punch/kick is standard and then after that, the combo combinations can either be healing, damage, recharge (of special attacks), or link/extend (boosts effects of previous node). The farther in each combo a node is placed, the stronger effect it is. These nodes can be changed at anytime in or out of combat, allowing for a strong damage combo to instantly be changed out for one that heals if you are low on health, or recharge if you need a special attack and quick! Fighting sequences were well spread and bosses were unique, but each was defeated in similar mannor. Attack when boss is idle, dodge when attacking, and do a quicktime event-like sequence for the final blow. Combat, i feel, could have been removed or re-vamped, but the change in pace from story to combat is pleasant and added to the storyline of the game.

Environment:
All the scenery and graphics were absolutely stunning. I took a few screenshots at key points which really show the beauty of this game. Because of this, it was a bit laggy at times, but i attribute that more to my computer being on the low-end, spec wise, not the game. Each map/area had little areas which could be explored, pick-ups which increase stats, and pacs which give even more backstory to this immersive game.

Controls:
Not much to say for controls. At times, I couldn't hit keys at the right time, but its much more a personal thing then key-mapping. I didn't encounter too many issues otherwise, nothing which was immersion-breaking.

Replayability:
Since this game is linear and follows the same storyline each time (to the best of my knowledge), there is no point to re-play the game unless a period of time has past and you want to re-live the story, or to 100% the game by finding all the little story pacs and power-ups.

reviewText:
Remember Me is a hard game to recommend outright. As a whole it is a largely linear campaign with plaforming sections. You basically go from platforming to combat room to more platforming. The game does try to be unique with the create - a - combo mechanic that was fun to mess with even though you'll be pressing the same two buttons most of the time.  The memory scrubbing that you do are like modified cut scenes that you play with going back and forth to find the best way to achieve the objective.

Now, I am a huge cyberpunk fan. And the setting is the main reason why I bought this game in the first place.  The gameplay and story kept me going to the end. And, that is pretty much all I ask of a game like this. In the end, I am happy I played it.

I recommend it if you can find it on sale.  Since this such a short game, this is a game that is worth your time.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This one is a hard recommendation. For all the things Remember Me does right, so many others it does wrong. I try to explain following my experience the first time I started the game up to the last second in which I unlocked all achievments for it and deleted it from my harddrive. So here it goes:

==Story==
At first I was confused. I played, things got explained to me, I didn't really care. Something about evil cooperations, and memory hunters of which our lead chracter is part of. We're playing Nilin, who lost her memories and gets guided to her rescue through some dude called Edge before the evil cooperation could delete the rest of her memories. The game is divided into episodes and with each episode we try to help Nilin remember more of her memory and in the end trying to stop the evil cooperation. It's a well written story but it unfolds very slowly and uninteresting. The stories high-point are the interactive memory remixes. As a memory hunter Nilin lets the player break into someone elses memory and alter it to his liking, thus changing persons attitude forwards certain events in the past, affecting the future. Cutscenes in this game can't be skipped.

==Gameplay / Combat==
The gameplay is your typical modern 3rd-person action game. There are linear corridors, climbing sections and arenas in which the Batman-like combat takes places. Combat is fast & fluid. The game allows you to customize from 3 to 8 hit long combo-chains that unlock over time.

The chains can be filled & customized through added presens. There are power presens and even presens that heal Nilin when she strikes. Later special abilities are introduced as well, so called S-presens. S-presens allow to stun enemies, manipulate robot foes, making your invisible for a short time to strike hard etc. Special Abilities have a cooldown. The cooldown can be reduced by adding cooldown reducing presens to your combo chains. There are also multiplier that can be added to the chains. These double the effect of previous presens in the combo chain. In the middle of a combo Nilin can dodge attack enemies and continue her combo. It sounds like a neat idea and it is IF combos wouldn't break each time Nilin strikes a different foe as the one she started the combo at. This can be very frustrating and it is and would explain why people think the combat is bad. But I enjoyed it due the possibility to change my combos accordingly to the enemies I was facing.

==Visuals & Sound==
The game looks gorgeous on highest setting. The only problem I encountered with the game is the constant studder due to Unreal3's texture streaming. There are certain ways to reduce or get rid of the studder on most systems. The soundtrack is a weird mix of electronic noises. The idea behind the music is that during combat a beat is played and each time a combo breaks or Nilin gets hit my an enemy the beat breaks too. But then there are instances in which overly epic music is played too loud that doesnt really fit with the shown scenes.

==Replay Value==
I mentioned that cutscenes can't be skipped. It's tedious to replay certain chapters to collect missing collectibles or to reach a certain point or fight that requires certain actions to unlock missing achievments. Having a collectible / achievment guide by your side comes in very handy. On the plus side: Once you finished the game Nilin will keep all her unlocked abilities and presens (even thouh abilities can only be used from the point onward in which they are unlocked during the story).

==Conclusion==
So why do I recomment the game? It's a short game delivering an well written and interesting story. It takes time to get used to the combat but once combos & presens are fully unlocked someone can have a blast with it. Achievment Hunters can also get their fair share of fun since It's easy to unlock those. But after you have done all that is to do in the game there is no big motivation to return to it. The story and the well done memory remixes are still worth to give the game a go.

reviewText:
Remember Me is just a great game. The game takes place in Neo-Paris in 2084, and it looks beautiful. The way the areas are designed, and how the game progresses is great. The story is also amazing, dealing with memories and how they are bought and sold and shared between people and used as currency. It's very deep and the story around Nilin is very, very interesting.

The combat is also pretty great. You get to customize your combos using 'pressens'. Having multiple types of pressens that can improve your damage, heal, reduce the cooldown of your s-pressens, e.t.c.. You can make your combo's look pretty awesome or just plain silly, but it's pretty unique in it's own way.

Also, seeing as this is a PC port it has been done really well. The PC controls with mouse and keyboard are really great minus the fact the s-pressen menu (q) is pretty buggy at times. I totally recomment mouse and keyboard over using a gamepad for this beat em up game.

reviewText:
This game tells an incredibly compelling story, and even though I didn't get to make any choices along the way I truly felt sick about some of the sacrifices Nilin is forced to make for the greater good.

The camera is sometimes annoying or even outright infuriating, and there's a severe shortage of actual memory-based combat for a game advertised as one in which you use your enemies' memories against them, but the combat the game does have is very fluid, and while most of the time I stuck to a simple, tried-and-true combo, a variety of enemies force you to change up your tactics and flex your wings in ways you otherwise never would have.

Ultimately this is a game well worth it for the story alone, and I strongly recommend it. You can read my more complete review here[kromey.us].
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Okay, Remember Me is a good game. It is absolutely stunning even on lower graphics settings, with a gorgeous cyberpunk setting and beautiful (if very, very linear) environment, and has an interesting story and compelling main character that made me want to play it all the way through. It also has a terrific soundtrack.

All of that said, the gameplay gets difficult and tedious quite early on. Combat simply takes too long and is too predictable for it to be really fun, especially during boss fights where missing a single quick-time event (which flash up extremely quickly) will force you to get that last bit of health down again (and again). I feel like a simple counter button would have helped speed things along a lot, given that the only way to avoid attacks without it is dodging (pretty much always breaking your combo).

Other minor complaints I have would be the fiddly, fiddly controls during the remix sequences (otherwise a very neat and interesting addition), and some of the dialogue writing - it often sounds very false and purple-prose-ish, particularly whenever Edge is on the line. I don't find that it detracts overly from the story, it's just a little jarring at times.

Like I said, Remember Me is still a good game, and I would recommend it if you're looking for a interesting story and a great main character (how many non-white female protagonists do we get in video games at the moment?). I definitely also recommend, however, waiting for a good sale, and preparing for a few rage quit moments along the way.

reviewText: Great original IP and a fresh look at cyberpunk from a more modern perspective by dropping you straight into a second-life as an augmented human! This is a fast fighting game and a great platformer all in one, though the mechanics could be stronger its so fresh to see a game like this readily available in the PC space from the get go.\n\nThe price point is perfect for the length and the amount of high quality artwork, unlike alot of modern action titles. I cannot recommend this game enough for fans of this style, its a must play for any fan of the genre and dispite having to battle a few bugs (no pun intended) I came away error free.

reviewText:
So this game was awesome, but not without it's problems.

The graphics were gorgeous, the soundtrack was topnotch, and the story was refreshing. The only thing this game really missed on was the combat.

That's not to say that the combat isn't good... it just doesn't... feel good after a while. The game's method of increasing difficulty ends up throwing more and more baddies at you in a never ending stream of punching bags. The boss fights are also something of a bore. Most of them consist of 'Use DOS, proceed to win'.
The, well, spamminess of the spammer is also a little dull on the last few boss fights (there's a prompt that actually reads 'SPAM').
There's also some wierd camera shifts while on the platforming bits of the game, and sometimes the controls shifted in wonky directions, resulting in a few frustrating deaths.

Probably the biggest letdown of this game is the lack of actual memory rewriting you do in the story line. This part of the game comes in relatively early, but then you spend a good couple hours before coming upon your next 'victim'. In total there were maybe 4 instances where your character did what your character was supposed to be known for doing. Rewriting memories should have taken a bigger role in the actual gameplay outside of the few times it was used after boss battles.

Despite its shortcomings, this game is amazing. It's a shame so few people have heard of/played it.

9/10 would play again. I'll probably end up buying this game as a gift for my friends when the holidays roll around this year.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Remember Me is very much a mixed bag. The story, setting and visual quality of the game go a long way to help it stand out from other titles, helping it cement an identity as a promising new IP. Sadly, the game is also held back by an underdeveloped combat system, often frustrating enemies, and one of the most linear beat-em-up experiences of recent memory. Saying this, there is some fun to be had out of Remember Me. Combat can occasionally be fun, especially when trying out new combos and S-Pressens, and boss encounters are particularly memorable and well designed. With all that’s been said, Remember Me just doesn’t live up to its potential. A setting and story this good deserves to be expanded upon in bigger, more ambitious games. Quote from awesomegames.

reviewText:
Remember Me is set in future Paris in a world where Memories are digitized and people able to erase or even change them. First impressions are very good. The artdesign, various landmarks in Paris, all affected by this futuristic setting, is incredible, accompanied by a fantastic musical score that combines orchestral instruments with digitized effects. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d2nZCIJpLRM If theres one award Remember Me deserved in 2013 it's definitely Best Soundtrack.

Since the world of Neo-Paris has banished firearms, the game evolves around punching dudes and avoiding getting punched. It is very reminiscent of God Hand on the Playstation 2. You create your own combos and by executing them well you earn bonuses like reducing cooldowns on your skills or healing yourself. In theory nice, but it is sadly very poorly executed. While in the early stages of the game the combat is kinda fun and has a good pace to it, especially towards the later parts of the game they throw way too many enemies at you. The lockon system is not very good so you end up hitting the wrong guy a lot and disrupting your combo. In the last third a lot of new enemy types are introduced that are very anti-fun and make the combat boring and tedious.

I really liked the various ways the theme of amnesia is implemented into the game, not just music and fighting, for example they make you memorize screenshots of locations where collectibles can be found minutes before you actually get to that spot. The memory remixing" minigames are really well done and even serve as narrative platforms
date: I wish there would have been more though.\n\nI still recommend Remember Me for its very interesting world. The story carries it a lot too
recommended: albeit some poor voice acting and dialogue it convinces with a strong beginning and a memorable ending. It's a shame that the gameplay is forgettable."
