reviewText:
Roughly 20+ hours, medium setting and 90% - finished.

Really good about 8 out of 10 impo... A very strong story with some very original mechanics specifically woven with the concept of the game's story which is completely original to my knowledge. Musically charming, fantastic artwork and quality conceptualisation with a very believeable background running up and side offering of readables building it's universe. Unlike a lot of modernized futuristic games, it does bear it's own unique identity that is very appealing about it and makes you stop and look if you're into Sci Fi and games that offer something more than point click (bang) shoot em ups. But it only falls short of the open world side that obviously allows titles like Deus Ex to triumph due to it's designing, but you can still miss in game upgrades and artsy things by not going down dead end corridors or rushing through, which at no point are you really forced to, (I'll certainly be replaying sections).

It incorporates fighting that is very similar to the Batman series and boss fights, with some exceptional fighting extras that are very fun and interesting to decipher including a design it yourself fight move User Interface. You have climbing that is very much similar to the Assassins creed series, puzzles reminiscent of both the previous titles mentioned but delivered wholly & uniquely enough to stand on it's own merit. You do have an environment with a set path and story to go through, you can't unless just for admiring purposes stand on one spot or go down every alley way or on every rooftop like Deus ex for example, it's a 3rd person view and if the second title is bold enough to be first person and then third person for fight sequences (or optional) it will save itself and make it with all the previous title's exceptionaly strong ingredients probably one of the best anticipated future titles due as a contender, it has so much of a world to offer it's designated format unfortunately cuts it short and limits it's immersive appreciability making it underrated and not fully able to deliver every nook and cranny of excellence it truly is, - thank you it was awesome!

-Industrialism (Thiervery TuT) UK

reviewText:
Remember Me is one of those titles I would never have gotten around to play if it wasn't for a grand sale.

If I had to give it a score I would rate it 7/10

Pros:
+ Strong female lead with a great character development
+ Great character development for other characters despite the short time you act around and with them
+ Easy to master combat
+ Great story
+ Some nice plot twists here and there
+ Beautiful enviroment
+ Good voice acting
+ A nice feeling of progression (new combos, unlocks and different Mini games" that come along when you progress)
+ Lots of different gameplay (Again
date:
lots of "mini games")
+ Tons of checkpoints
+ Super useful collectables
+ Combat crafting

Cons:
- Super linear
- Easy to master combat
- No options to change outcome and story of the game
- Only one ending
- Not nearly enough time spent with other characters at all
- Repititive combat
- Took me 12 hours to finish (2.25 euros pr. hour if full price was paid)
- A few easily forgetable characters (because they didn't get enough time to develop and be a part of the story)
- A ton of checkpoints
- Bad camera angles at times (Annoyed me at max 3-4 times)
The list of cons might sound large

reviewText: I was really excited to play this game when I read about how most game sites didn't want to shine light to the fact it was being released. When I played it and tried to indulge in the story, I did find myself wanting to play all the way through. I loved the perspective of the storyline, atmosphere and setting of this game. I also really enjoyed the fighting style. However, this game doesn't really let you explore neo paris like you would hope to. Each mission is in sections, once you've moved forward, you can't go back unless you restart. I would have loved to roam around this game more. I think it has so much potential and if you're looking to get this game, keep in mind you may finish the game quite fast, other then gaining all the achievements theres not much else to do with the game.

reviewText:
Tl;DR - beautiful game with medicore gameplay, very good setting and a pretty good story. Overall 7/10.

Those are the 4 elements I'll be writing about. Let's start with what this game surprised me the most - the visuals. Art direction in this game is astounding. The colors, light, graffities, models, all tell the story of the Neo-Paris. Despite the fact that the assets themselves are not really good quality (not bad either though, especially considering it was a previous gen game) the game still has a lot of wow moments and it's all thanks to a very smart and beautiful usage of the listed elements.

That, alongside multiple dialogues, fluff announcments audible in the background and notes found as collectibles creates a very detailed, believable and scary vision of the late 21st century. However, the world was not used correctly, in my opinion. Personally I wish we'd spend more time on the streets of the city, watching how the people live, what problems they have etc. We've only heared or read about the world (which again, was done very well), but almost never saw it, spending most of the time in some labs/prisons etc. That was one of my big issues with the game, lots of wasted potential there.

Learning about the world and seeing the beautiful environment was what kept me playing most of the time, as the rest was rather obvious from the start.

Story set in this world is not as good as it could be. It's full of cliche solutions, lacks any choice and sometimes it's hard to emphasise with main character's actions. The story itself lacked something more inventive, unusual.

Finaly - gameplay. Most of the game is split into 2 sections - Batman-esque fights and exploration. Both aspects are done poorly. There's very few enemies and most of them are more or less the same. Instead of introducing new, more complicated opponents, at later stages the game becomes more difficult just by throwing in more enemies. It clearly tried to go full Batman, but failed (also, it gets boring at this point too). Combo system associated with the combat also felt lackluster. By the time I've finished the game I had 3 full combos and 1 unfinished one. Instead of building a database of my combos that I could use as I see fit, depending on the situation, in the end I just built 2 universal ones that I used all the time, depending if I needed utility (most of the time) or damage (rather rarely). Exploration left some to be desired as well - you can only climb the very specific objects that the game allows you to, so pretty much if you can climb something - you should. It was done similarly to Enslaved: Odyssey to the west, where you just moved the stick, pressed the jump button and watch your character perform animations. No room to fail, no challange, no threat. Just a filler.

The unique gameplay element, that also has to be mentioned, was the memory rewriting. Sounds very cool and about half of the time it was, but the other half, at least to me, felt rather unlogical. The solution to the problem felt random, which led to continous rewinding just to try another, sensless combination. Additionaly it lacked a functionality that would improve the system in general (not the unlogical sections, though) - ability to quickly jump to identified memory glitches and changing them much faster that way.

In the end I still recommend this game, a bit. It's not great, but it's good. It has increadibly well done elements, some pretty good ones and if you don't bounce off the medicore ones, you might still have fun.

reviewText: I can definitely recommend this game. It has intriguing, well written story, really good graphics (Landscapes are stunning) and enjoyable, dynamic gameplay. The music is also nice. As for the combat system - in my opinion it's simple but enjoyable. Fights are dynamic, some of them are even quite challenging. Looking for hidden objects is a nice addition. The overall concept for game world is interesting and rich in medium and little details creating the full image of the fictional society and its' problems.\nThe worst part of the game are scripted behaviours of player character. Every few minutes you receive a call, which is of course very important for plot, but during the conversation you suddenly can only walk slowly, it's often impossible to jump through a gap, so you have to wait until the conversation is over. And some other conversations don't have such limits and you can run freely. And of course you can't skip any of the cinematics. Many players won't be annoyed by it on the first playthrough, but on the second it becomes quite irritating.\nTo sum up: It's a very good game, with great concept, but a few lacks in this concept's realisation. Definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
DONTNOD did a fantastic job on this game. The concept is great, and I love the multifaceted game mechanics. The combat is sometimes frustrating, but I found myself actually enjoying attempting to hit combos by the end.

The story is engaging and reflective of the human condition, and I enjoyed the game from start to finish. I wish however, that it had been more open-world, and that they had expanded a little more. The more open world vibe of 2013 Tomb Raider would have suited this game so well. Only complaint is that I wanted more. I was engrossed in the world.

That being said, excellent music, voice acting, graphics and a wide array of enemies to keep you on your toes. DEFINITELY worth picking up.

reviewText:
Make no mistake, this game is a delight to look at.  The city of Neo-Paris has been rendered in a way that lends considerable creedence to their vision of the near future.  Lots of little details are included that make the environments believable.
That task was probably made easier by the highly-linear nature of the game.  On the one hand, you can lament how incredible this would have been to have the same level of detail in an open-world, but the linear nature allows for a high degree of polish on the path you follow through the world and story.
The story's competent, and told well enough, though I don't think I was invested as the story expected me to be.  Nilin comes across as introspective, yet more than a little cold.
There's a neat memory-remix mechanic introduced early on and it felt like I was nearly halfway through the game before it came up again, though there are several instances before all's said and done.  I'll echo the sentiments of several other reviewers who wished there was more of that
date: please."\nThe combat itself is also competent
recommended: in the Arkham vein but with a dodge rather than a counter
hoursPlayed: with a few nice touches to spice things up.  Depending on your play style

reviewText:
Remember Me is a linear SciFi story with batman-style combat and tombraider-style movement. And Lord of the Rings is about a little guy who carries around a ring.

Lets get serious again... it has good art, very nice sound track, nice animations. The world is fancy and entertaining but the real star is the story, it is a rare example of smart scifi which touches heart and mind equally well. There are also some unique minigames like changing the memory of people. Also the balance between exploring, combat, puzzles and mini games is good.

Surelly there is some bad stuff too, the game is totally linear (but trust me you wont mind), has only auto save points (but lots of em), has little replay value, a couple of little bugs (had to restart the game 3-4 times), things sometimes get a little repetitive (but only slightly) and some battles and quick time events are a little bit unbalanced. Also while the old Paris" scenery was gorgeous there was too much "that sewer again" and "yet another generic scifi service tunnel". Sometimes I stepped through a door which immediatly locks and I lose my chance to explore some more rooms. No serious problems but definitly not perfect.

Would I buy again? Absolutely. I have enjoyed every minute of it. 8 out of 10 points.
"

reviewText:
PC Specs (If you care):
~
Alienware 15 R2 Laptop
Intel Core i7 6700HQ CPU @ 2.6 ghz Turbo Boosted at 3.5 ghz, 4 Cores, 8 Logical Processors
8gbs RAM
Nvidia Geforce GTX 970M
Windows 10 Home
~
Remember Me is a game that takes place in a 2080's, futuristic Paris. It is a story-driven game made by DONTNOD Entertainment (Life is Strange). It has beautiful graphics and a great storyline keeping you on the edge of your seat wanting to play more and more. It is split up into 8 episodes that take place in different areas around Paris and normally introduce new enemies changing the rules of the game.
~
Pros:
-Great Graphics
-Awesome Storyline
-Multiple Gameplay Mechanics
-Constant Changing of Mechanics
-No Bugs/Glitches

Cons:
-Repetitive Combat
-Rage Inducing

~

Gameplay:
The gameplay in this game consists of making your own combos and using them to your advantage. Before or during a fight you can go into the combo lab and change your combos to appeal to the enemies your fighting. Combos are used with X and Y (Example: X, Y, Y, X, Y) and there are 4 different combo slots and combo moves to implement. You can outfit your combos with a Damage Multiplier, Health Regenerator, Cooldown Regenerator, or Loop.
Aside from the combat there is Parkour. The parkour in this game is very straightforward, you cannot pick your path. The game is set on one path the entire time that you have to follow, no branching out on another for a different outcome in the end. While doing parkour there is an orange arrow that follows you around and tells you where to go, making the game annoying because it's always telling you where to go.

7.5/10 I would recommend this game to you and all of your friends.

reviewText:
Very pretty but clunky brawler with some really interesting story ideas.

--------

+ Great setting.
+ Interesting and smart story.
+ Cool character designs.
+ Good graphics.
+ Memory remixes.

+/- Hidden collectables.

- Clunky, basic combat.
- Annoying combat camera.
- Linear, predetermined platforming.
- Feels like it drags on a little bit.

----

Remember Me is a game full of interesting ideas, some of which work and some of which unfortunately do not.

The story is both interesting, and does that thing all good science fiction does by feeling like a relevant reflection upon the difficulties in our lives. I feel like it would have benefitted more from really focusing on that aspect rather than proceeding as it did, however.

The combat gameplay is akin to that seen in the Arkham Batman games, except without the countering or dynamism. It includes a system of designing your own combos that manages to feel very limiting as opposed to the freedom an idea like that should give. The combat camera is also less than helpful, often causing enemies to begin their attacks from off screen which obscures the visual warning. One aspect I did like however was the special Pressen" attacks you could use. After charging a gauge in combat you can opt to unleash one of several special attacks for a variety of devastating effects.

The environmental traversal gameplay is a case of follow the clearly marked climbing path with literal flashing arrows telling you where to go and being unable to deviate in any way. Cinematically this is okay - watching someone climb is more interesting than running down a long corridor I suppose - but it would be nice to be able to actually explore the world a bit more or for there to be some kind of a challenge involved. The gorgeous landscape absolutely begs for it.

Overall
date: Remember Me is worth playing for it's excellent sci-fi memory dystopia world and for it's memorable "memory remix" segments. It has some good cinematic set pieces and graphically looks great but don't expect to be impressed by the combat or climbing."

The worst technical sin, however, is that the gameplay and visuals are obstructed by the very narrow FOV.  Even on a 30 LCD panel

reviewText: I'm on the fence about actually recommending this game. It has a gorgeous world and level design with a beautiful soundtrack and great character / enemy designs. It also has an intriguing lore with good voice acting. Gameplay and combat are decent, but the game as a whole is short and many of the ethics and issues that are brought up in conversations are never fully discussed. This game could have been much more engrossing and thought provoking, especially when the best aspect of the game, the memory remixing, is under used. In the end, I am going to recommend this game (flaws and all) because of the need to support new IPs and female protagonists in gaming. Not worth full price, but certainly worth a look.

reviewText:
The first game released by Dontnod and not an entirely bad one either. Funny enough, I played Life is strange without knowing who developed it and wondered why something seemed familiar....
What is it? It's a 3rd person action/beat-em up/platformer set in the future. It has some heavy Bladerunner and Mirrors edge influences and you can tell from the color scheme.
Graphically it's pretty decent for an U3 engine game, as you'd expect and ran well for my rig. Some amazing city scapes, nice lighting and heavy reflections make this game look crisp and futuristic.
Never mind the fact that you spend most of the time trudging through gritty lower level Paris neighborhoods and sewers but it makes the moments you are travelling though some very high tech looking areas more appreciated.
The sound and music for some reason reminded me a little of the Tron 2.0 game from way back, it suits the game, especially during the combat sequences, very punchy.
Speaking of combat, it's mostly hand to hand. You time your punches and kicks to form a chain (combo ), pre-determined by which button you press. See, using a gamepad, it would be something like xxx, or xyyxyy or yxyxy but the really great thing about this games combat is that you can program/create your own combo as long as it follows the button sequence. For example, pressens (damage, health, special attack cooldown and Multiply?) can be programmed to the button you press in the sequence. I could create an attack chain starting with damage, followed by health steal on the second hit, followed by a cooldown to my special attack on the third hit, then another damage and finish with multiply. Mix a combo any way you want! I mean it's not freeflowing like Batman Arkham games but it's close. And sadly that's also a bad point, there isn't enough combat or it's all or nothing.

Sadly, the game space itself feels a little narrow and linear. A lot of the time you're walking down a hallway to turn into an open room to follow another hallway. The platforming is pretty dull and it felt like the game was holding you're hand a lot as you play through it. Never-the-less, the game looks amazing while you are walking around in a straightforward manner.

It feels good to play though, very fluid movements as LONG AS YOU HAVE A GAMEPAD! I can't stress enough how much better it is to play with a controller. I much prefer using a keyboard and mouse with my games but I feel it's essential to play this particular game with a pad!
The character movements are nice, very fluid! I've walked up and down stairs so many times and I've got to say they've nailed movement nicely!

So in a nutshell....OK combat, just not enough of it. Good music and sound effects. Fantastic graphics for an UE3 game. Story...ho hum, interesting concept with a couple of What the! moments.
It's a great game, maybe under appreciated.

reviewText:
Forget you soon.
The Good
Damn. Before I played Remember Me, I've been told quite frequently that it was a mixed bag, but nothing could have prepared me for this. After a short introduction, you find yourself in the incredibly stylised Neo-Paris, which is without a doubt its best asset. The visual design is one of the most beautiful locations I have ever experienced. Everything is perfect. The city itself, the buildings, the denseness of everything, the neon lights, the struggling people, the robots.  The atmosphere is amazing as well, both the environmental sound design and the soundtrack. Everything screams cyberpunk. But how about the inside, under the hood?

The Bad
You see, while the outside is one of the most gorgeous settings, the actual game is riddled with flaws. It's one of the very few games I wish had a film or animated film set in the same universe, because it doesn't play well. The incredible design of Neo-Paris yearns to be explored, to be discovered and appreciated. Instead, you're walking an awfully straight linear path, and most of the times basically a hallway with nice decorations. It's such a shame, and I wonder how greatly this game would have benefited from an open-ended design with a focus on exploration.

Besides the linear level design, the combat system is also rather unappealing. Making your own combos sound pretty good on paper, but the fighting itself just isn't a lot of fun. Pardon the metaphor, but it feels like the mentally challenged niece of the Batman Arkham series. And to make matters worse, you'll be fighting pretty frequently. The enemy placements are illogical, there's no thought behind it, except for artificially increasing the game length.

Besides those two big flaws, I've also experienced some smaller flaws. The story is pretty uninteresting, and the characters are even less so. Which is a shame, because th. Also, the collectibles are pretty useless, since you can easily and very quickly regain your Health and Pressens through the Regen and Cooldown moves in your combos.

In short:

+ Incredible visual design, one of the most highly stylised settings I have ever seen.
+ Soundtrack is good.
+ HUD disappears outside of combat, which makes for a very clean screen.
+ Mixing memories can be pretty fun.

- Extremely linear, a huge waste of Neo-Paris.
- Uninteresting story with uninteresting characters.
- Mediocre combat system.
- Fighting the same enemies with little diversity is tiring.
- Final boss is stupid and misplaced.
- Collectibles are basically useless.

reviewText:
Remember me is the kind of fighting game, that if you're not into fighting games, you just might want to make an exception for this one. Remember me is a fighting game with a lot of RPG elements in it - so much, actually, that a lot of players have critisized it for being too linear, forgetting it's true nature. It's a visual masterpiece IF you're into visual beauty but then again it's just one aspect that makes this game as awsome as it is. Some parts of the level design does feel like a rip-off from other games, for example the beginning totally looks like Dishonored and Bastille looks like Citadel form Half-Life 2 but instead of holding it against them, I felt happy to rediscover those places in another context. I agree with the overall consensus that the main character is one of the key elements, that make this game what it is. We have a female protagonist, racially diverse AND with a compelling history. She fights like a badass and makes tough descisions throughout the game. It's one of my all time favorites. Below are pros and cons:

Pros:
+ Incredibly beautiful cityscape (reminds the movie Fifth Element).
+ Supreme level design.
+ Interesting futuristic story.
+ Interesting character build and choices she has to face.
+ Customizable fighting combos.
+ Really useful powers/ abilities.
+ Visually the fighting sequences are a masterpiece.
+ Tactical approach to battles.
+ Build your own combos.
+ Supreme dodging mechanics that make battles dynamic, rapid and visually marvellous.
+ Apart from many other players, I actually liked the QTE endings of boss battles, that gave a meaning to the cinematic killmoves.

Cons:
- One gamebreaking bug in the worst place imaginable - right after a boss battle, forcing you to replay the lengthy fight.
- Main character's face should have been modelled, textured and animated better since you see it so often in the game.

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Third Person Action game in a semi-dystopian world with intriguing story, but some buggy gameplay. The combat is mostly hand to hand with a simplified “combo” system where you alternate between punches and kicks. Overall it’s a fun game and makes you think about the benefits and drawbacks of memory manipulation.

You play Nilin, a “memory hunter” in a world where technology now allows the storage and deletion of human memories. Unlike the “Total Recall” movies, the technology can’t really make up new memories and implant them into people. Instead, it’s possible to selectively delete memories and/or remove them from people and give them to someone else. As a memory hunter, Nilin is able to do a whole lot of unusual things such as steal passwords from a person’s mind, “remix” memories, and use cyber power attacks in combat.

The game is mostly linear with a lot of free climbing like Assassin’s Creed or Tomb Raider games, and the combat is similar to the brawling in the Batman Arkham games or Sleeping Dogs. However unlike Batman, Nilin doesn’t “counter” attacks, only dodge. Also, note that unlike the Arkham games the reaction time is shorter (You pretty much have to dodge as soon as you see an attack warning). The combo system I mentioned earlier is based around unlocking punches and kicks as you “level up.”  These attacks can be chained into 3, 5, 6, or 8 hit combos which do increasing damage as they get longer. This is why the short reaction time to enemy attacks is so annoying (they keep interrupting combos).  Other special powers you can unlock throughout the story are Fury (short term damage boost), DOS (area effect stun), Logic Bomb (area affect damage) along with a couple others.

Pros:
+A unique and complex world with a thought provoking story line.
+The boss battles are interesting because of cyber manipulation of virtual worlds based around memories.
+The “memory remix” sections of the game let you view and make subtle changes to a person’s memory, with the overall effect of making them remember things that never happened. It’s like the butterfly effect in action, tiny changes can change the outcome in drastic ways.

Cons:
-The game has some noticeable bugs, like the sound suddenly cutting out, or not being able to aim your spammer “gun” at various points in the game.
-The combat system is really annoying when you’re surrounded by enemies and can’t get a combo going because everyone keeps attacking. In the Batman games, the enemies usually attack one at a time (or you can use a multi-takedown). In Remember Me, you have to dodge and start your combo over.

You probably have Remember Me from the Humble Bundle last year so don’t be afraid to give it a shot.

reviewText:
Overview Remember Me is a 3rd person, cyberpunk video game by DONTNOD Entertainment. It features a genuinely entertaining world, decent storytelling, and a frustratingly monotonous combat system that is at the same time, satisfyingly intense. Its visuals are stunning and its architecture is absolutely superb. But how does this all gel together into one game? In this review I'll be going over the visuals, gameplay, game world, and some closing thoughts.

Visuals Remember Me is absolutely gorgeous. It blends a unique art style, great lighting, realistic architecture and human faces, all tied up by fluid animations. The whole experience just breaths sci-fi/cyberpunk. The only thing I can knock on as far as graphics go are some of the textures which, while high res, are often very plain. What I mean by this is that everything frequently seems a bit too stark and barren. This in its own right is not a very strong argument though, as it definitely fits with the clean, futuristic look that DONTNOD was obviously going for, it just happened to get a bit old. Not really much else to say here, which is a good thing. I never found any graphical issues, Remember Me was simply an impressive sight to behold. And yes, I think the visuals hold up even now, in the first quarter of 2016.

Gameplay Gameplay is probably the most frustrating part of Remember Me. If the dev's could have simply put a little bit of extra love and care into the systems that govern the games mechanics, it would have gone a long way. The combat is fun to watch and a total spectacle, but is far too repetitive and samey throughout the entirety of the game. The only redeeming quality of the fighting in Remember Me is that it has some challenging battles, which forms some nice tense moments in the minute to minute gameplay. Other than that, I'd say the combat is totally mediocre. The next most prevalent part of the gameplay is the platforming. It is almost completely linear, which is a strike right off the bat. It takes absolutely no skill, and it's really just used as filler. Not exciting or fun in any way. However, the gameplay does have a certain instance in which lots of thought was put into, which was the remix puzzle sections. These are sequences in which your character enters a specific memory of another individual, and makes small adjustments that leads to their memory of a certain event becoming completely warped, which then helps you on your way through Remember Me's linear story. This is about all Remember Me offers as far as gameplay goes. I will, however, say that I don't agree with those saying it would have been better served by being a movie, as the game world is something that should be experienced by the individual, with their input rather than some director. And with that, let's get into what I just stated as the driving factor for this game, the world.

Game World The game world of Remember Me is easily where it most excels. It's stylish, intriguing, well designed, and very fun to immerse yourself within. It is a world that proves its uniqueness, as well as its authenticity. I often had to stop and take in the layout of the levels, just to admire it all. Pair all of these points with the sci-fi atmosphere, and you have a world that is near irresistible to many kinds of gamers. If you value a games immersion and design, you will absolutely feel at home with Remember Me.

Final Thoughts While there are many things to criticize about Remember Me, I feel that when looking at the big picture, the vast majority of my complaints fade. This was the first project of DONTNOD Entertainment, and they have since release the episodic-adventure game Life is Strange"
date: which is critically acclaimed. With that fact

reviewText:
I've had a few gripes with my first playthrough so far, mostly when it came to the camera and the collectibles, but the game flows well, has beautiful visuals and unique characters, and some of the gameplay gimmicks are marvelously original.

I haven't spent a lot of time on this game yet obviously, but playing it on and off makes it an experience that is immersive and intense, yet somehow relaxing. The art direction on this game did very well on making the game less frustrating - I wouldn't mind fighting the same boss about three times if it meant I could experience that kind of eye candy again.

Of course, a game isn't always just about the visuals - I love the variety of the gameplay. You climb, puzzle and fight your way through different levels and along the way you gain more skills and moves that you can combine in a variety of ways. It did take some time to get used to it, though. The combat is different from what you'd expect, so be prepared to fumble around a little bit.

Overall, this game had everything I expected it to have. Character/racial diversity? Check. Gorgeous holograms and environments? Check. Linearity? Check. That satisfying feeling when something works? Definitely check.

I love this game. Please play it.

reviewText: If you are looking for a game that is set in a well crafted cyberpunk world, this is the one for you. The game's setting and world are definitely its strong point. From the streets of Neo-Paris to leaper infest tunnels, I'm enjoying it all. Everything is carefully detailed. Vendors have holograms advertisements, news screens highlight story details throughout. Androids can be spotted here and there doing various jobs. The graphics are great and the rendering of lighting effects and textures really compliment everything. Alleys of neon glow over wet concrete, the clash of metals and fabrics on Nilin. The aesthetic reminds me a lot of the style of Half-Life 2 / Dishonoured / Mirror's Edge.\n\nI think where this game didn't meet expectations was the combat mechanic. It seems the devs tried something new this time around instead of sticking to the normal combat in fighting games, and they should be appauded for trying, but it was probably better in theory. My experience with the combo system changed throughout the game. Early on they were intimidating, I thought I wouldn't be able to remember so many buttons. Later on it became tedious and took me out of the fun of combat, and late game I realized that combo building was crutial for some boss fights. Another thing that bothered me was the short delay between attacks or slow-down". Nilin feels so agile and quick

reviewText:
For sure I will remember this game!
--------------------------------------

Before I bought it, I looked for some reviews of this game on inumerous sites and, even with an average score, I decided to give it a try.

All right, this is not an open world game, it won't take more than 5~6 hours to finish it and the story is linear.

But, what's the matter about playing a linear story? A book is linear, a movie is linear, can't a good game be it too?

Even that you can't move freely through it, the environment is rich in details, the story is well narrated and the protagonist is so captivating that you want to discover her past and help her cause. For so many times I just relaxed and started to take screenshots to remember the places and the action scenes.

The combat system is quite fun. While you advance in the game, you can mix buttons to create COMBOS and easily execute them. But, this is not the BATMAN ARKHAM SERIES combat system, so you CAN'T have a free flow between enemies and link the created combos. So don't expect huge combos like DEVIL MAY CRY for example.

The Memory Remix is quite a piece of art. You really feel like you are in command. You can and you will modify people's memories to change history. And it's so easy and fun, that it invites you to try different combinations just to see what happens.

If you're not a big fan of Achievements, just let the game take you through the story. I started to look for colectibles like an Achievement Hunter and soon the game became boring. So I just started to play the game despite of looking for trophies and it was a much better experience.

So, to summarize it:

Nice story, great soundtrack, captivating protagonist, amazing memory remix moments and everything placed on a beautifull, yet limited, fantasy world.

Play it, you sure will remember.

And thats before I've even touched on any plot.

If you can find this cheaper than £30: GET IT. For £30 though I would suggest you look into what Remember is beyond the initial trailers.

reviewText:
I'm not sure why so many people didn't like this game; while not the greatest ever, it is a really enjoyable game with a unique story and features.  Sure, its very linear; but not every game has to be open-world.  Games with a strong narrative, such as Remember Me, would not work very well as an open-world game (the devs would have to impose annoying restrictions on where you go in the open-world anyway to enforce any kind of narrative).  So, if you're looking for GTA or something, this isn't for you.

That said, the story is very compelling: you are a memory hunter whose memories have been stolen in a future-parisian city where memories can be traded, bought, and sold.  The gameplay reminds me of something like Uncharted or Tomb Raider where you have to climb around, jumping and hanging from ledges.  The fighting, which can get a little repetitive is like a not-as-good version of the fighting from the Batman: Arkham Asylum games with some sci-fi elements thrown in.  However, the memory remix sequences were some of my favorite parts and something truly unique to Remember Me.  Basically, you can scroll through someone's memory and make tiny alterations to change how they remember what happened; for example, you can turn the safety off on their gun and move a stool slightly, causing them to trip on the stool and the gun to accidentally fire, shooting someone else.  The soundtrack is also really amazing; I sometimes listen to it while working.  Graphically, the game is pretty impressive, especially the remix sequences and other memory areas, which are very stylized; especially when you use 3x1 Eyefinity :)

My only complaint with the game is that the fighting can get a little repetitive.

reviewText:
While it may not be the most revolutionary when it comes to gameplay otherwise, the REMIX scenes are immensely fantastic, and one of my few complaints is that there weren't ENOUGH of them. At a scant 4 scenes in the game, I feel the game under-utilized what could have been one of it's most fantastic mechanics.

The rest of the gameplay was fun, even though not very innovative.

Story was a B+, but still very enjoyable; and, there were several moments that I felt very emotionally attached to the game.

The best feature of this game is the absolutely fantastic score by Olivier Deriviere (who previously worked on Alone in the Dark 2005's score). An artful and amazing blending of electronica and orchestral makes this another hit soundtrack and on my top 10 playlists.

reviewText:
I've had a few gripes with my first playthrough so far, mostly when it came to the camera and the collectibles, but the game flows well, has beautiful visuals and unique characters, and some of the gameplay gimmicks are marvelously original.

I haven't spent a lot of time on this game yet obviously, but playing it on and off makes it an experience that is immersive and intense, yet somehow relaxing. The art direction on this game did very well on making the game less frustrating - I wouldn't mind fighting the same boss about three times if it meant I could experience that kind of eye candy again.

Of course, a game isn't always just about the visuals - I love the variety of the gameplay. You climb, puzzle and fight your way through different levels and along the way you gain more skills and moves that you can combine in a variety of ways. It did take some time to get used to it, though. The combat is different from what you'd expect, so be prepared to fumble around a little bit.

Overall, this game had everything I expected it to have. Character/racial diversity? Check. Gorgeous holograms and environments? Check. Linearity? Check. That satisfying feeling when something works? Definitely check.

I love this game. Please play it.

reviewText:
Okay, so a friend requested that I actually put some thought into my review of this game, and I was like... alright?

I am nearly done with it, going through to collect missed stuff...

Look, I am not gonna waste your time beating around the bush, the controls and fighting system are so effing bad.  I really do not like the combat in this title, which is a shame, as that is a majority of your gameplay.

The graphics are ...okayish, I am not big on who has the flashiest styles, so I don't care, but you might.  It is built on a dated engine, but it performed well.

So with combat and graphics out of the way, let's talk about the camera...

Rather, let us recall the days of camera locks and auto follows that kill you.  That is where we are at here, absolutely malfunctive camera, I died a lot due to falls caused by unwanted camera movement and it is also locked at times so that you cannot position it how you would want to see. Combined with the controls and you find death happening quite a lot if you don't watch out.

Okay, so camera, controls, combat... all suck, graphics are okayish... WHY SHOULD YOU BUY THIS GAME?

Well, honestly... the voice acting is pretty bad too... but the story is good, cliche at times but there is a lot of interesting stuff to think about after playing, or while playing.

I don't think this game was intended to be a blockbuster hit, but they did do a good enough job to interest me in their ideas and story.  The things they invisioned for the future of many technologies being worked on or existing today.  I think that their AR was an interesting way to show several of my friends what AR publishers want to do for us. (all that HUD type info)

If you see it on sale for 5 dollars or so, I would say it is worth about that.

reviewText: This game has been on my wishlist for a LONG time. I always looked over it because of such a backlog of games I've had to complete. reviewText:
So much great potential wasted with scrub tier mistakes.

GOOD
-Story
-World Building
-Writing(its a good story but not told so well)
-Combat combo system is neat and fun to mess with
-Dodging mechanic thats fast intuitive and fun
-Same Devs as Life is Strange though this is though Capcom and LiS is though Square Enix.

BAD
-Control (which destroys everything else)
Movement is tied not to the mouse just the camera is. So you often find yourself walking or going in a direction you dont want to or getting stuck in a corner somehwhere because movement is based on your characters orientaton not the cameras. Targeting sucks because of this as well. Its pretty much the root of every issue that comes up in the game and ruins immersion.
-QTE. Nuff said. Its not so punishing if you mess it up and its not RNG each time either. So its not so terrible but its still QTE.
-Repetitive boss quotes. There isnt even a delay between when they are said, its literally the same 2-3 quotes on loop. Prepare to hear the same line 6-7 times in 30 seconds. Not even kidding.
-Recycled content. Fight the same boss over again with no changes. Feels like padded gameplay
-No mechanic to stop you from just walking off a ledge to your death. Your character freely falls off any ledge to previous area you parkor'd up from or to your death. This + poor character control = no fun.

TL:DR I love the game and the idea. Shame it was let down with poor implimentation. Save your money and buy Life is Strange instead. Same devs MUCH MUCH better game. <3

reviewerDisplayName: The Double Derivitive of YA MUM!
reviewText:
Loyal readers and strangers of the internet, ‘tis I. It certainly has been a while, and I just know you’re all itching to read another page long review (This is the part you skip to the end, read the summary and leave.) Today you’re going to suffer through a review of a game that got huge amounts of hype, but was neglected when it game out. “Why?” you ask. Don’t interrupt me; I’m going to tell you why. What’s wrong with you? I go to all the trouble to write a review for the game, and you just come on in like you own the place. God, the nerve of you readers. Anyway, let us begin.

Remember Me is set almost 80 years in the future in “Neo-Paris.” (Which is future talk for “Paris.”) Society has been completely ruptured and as a result of new technology known as “Sensen” that allows real memories to be digitised, manufactured, sold, bought and traded. Because of this, people have chosen to remove or replace any bad memories. This has drastic effects on people’s personalities, which we see often in the game when a single altered memory can turn friend from foe. Throughout the game, we see too very distinct classes. The upper class, who live in a beautiful utopian society, without any cares. This contrasts with the majority of people, who live in decaying ruins, desperate for money, work, memories, Ect. As you can see, this game has an abstract, beautiful concept, above and beyond most games produced now (*Cough Cough FC3 Blood Dragon.*)

You take on the role of Nilin, an errorist agent who fights Memorise, the company who owns Sensen and have developed an immense power over 99% of the population, who are virtually addicted to Sensen. Nillin’s past shows her to be an elite errorist agent, capable of not only of stealing other’s memories, but altering and rewriting them. This power unlocks a unique mechanic that I’ll talk in a minute. You start the game in the clichéd manner of amnesia, having you memory recently been entirely wiped. The voice of the errorists, who goes by the name of “Edge” is the only thing that gets you out of the prison you and the other errorists are being kept in. As the game progresses, we see what the Sensen technology, despite having good intentions, has done to the world. In prisons, prisoners have their memories taken from them to prevent rebellions. People who have become so addicted to the technology, they’ve lost everything trying to afford it. However, as your actions, which are influenced by edge, have extremely negative consequences which impact on many innocent people, you start to doubt if you’re a vigilante, or a renegade.

Now, moving on to mechanics. Remember Me’s combat is primarily based on combos, comprised of left and right clicks and dodging. The basic idea was, you were given a combo. (E.G Punch, kick, kick, punch, kick, kick) and you can change the effects on these different attacks (E.g., one of the punches could do extra damage, another could heal you slightly, Ect) The dodging system was integrated quite well into the combat, with the exception that if you dodged, you would have to restart the combo. The system was very good, especially when integrated with different unlockable abilities which were all creative and innovative, and a single ranged weapons, although, neither of these things was crucial to combat. I liked the combat system all in all, what I didn’t like was how clunky it felt. Often, because there was no particular was to select your targets (which I honestly didn’t mind, don’t get me wrong) you would attack whichever enemy was closest, in range and looking at. This system reminded me of the Batman: Arkham series, although, unlike the Arkham games, there was no easy way to move from target to target. In fact, it was almost impossible. Another problem was that sometimes you would try and fight an enemy, and the game would outright choose a different target. I don’t blame the developers for this, but allowing freeflow would’ve reduced this problem. Finally, I found that combat was often too busy, especially with enemies such as Leapers, who could jump onto walls and stay there before producing an attack that can only be dodged. This meant that, if fighting a hoard of leapers, one would constantly have to be dodging, and that can be a bit trying, especially when you were unable to complete any combos.

The platforming aspect to the game had its problems as well. Every level design, regardless of how unique the art style, felt linear, like the world was closed, and didn’t exist short of this one path. The game even threw in little arrows on platforms you were meant to jump on, which was nice of them but really did take away the challenge of a platformer with such a strong puzzle aspect, although it was, undoubtedly, necessary, as the paths didn’t stick out like a sore thumb like they do in Assassin’s Creed (Seriously, God in that game must’ve been a parkourist.) All I’m saying is that this game would’ve sold much better with a slightly more open world.

I’m going to touch on the art style and soundtrack by saying that they’re both great. The art style really brought to life the contrasts of the classes of Neo-Paris and the soundtrack contributed heavily to the atmosphere

Finally, the mechanic that allows Nilin to enter somebodies memory and alter it was simply astounding. The way it was structured was a little bit of a trial at the time, having to re-watch the same cutscène over an over again to find memory glitches (Things in the memory you can change) and having you go back and select different glitches to change the outcome was tedious, especially because you had to deselect everything before re-watching the cutscène to find out what was wrong. Not even mentioning how memory glitches were only fractions of seconds long. I didn’t miss any memory glitches (Their animation was just the right amount of subtle to make it difficult, but entirely possible to find them if you were paying attention) but rewinding and replaying and pausing and fast forwarding and rewinding again trying to land on the exact place where the glitch was, was severely annoying, especially later on when they become even shorter.

SUMMARY:
Look, this game really tried to be a classic. Its storyline, art style, soundtrack and voice acting easily qualify. However, the clunky mechanics and linear environment didn’t work in the games favour. I enjoyed playing this game, but only for its storyline. It almost felt like it would’ve made a better movie than a game.

Storyline 10/10
Mechanics 4/10
Art style & Soundtrack 9/10

Overall: 7.5/10
Thanks for reading.
P.S, the game is pretty demanding of your computer, maybe free up some space or improve the RAM. You’ve been warned

reviewText:
Played through about an hour of Remember Me. Here are my first impressions.

The story and polish on this game are outstanding. I absolutely love the world and theme that they've created here. Unfortunately, I came to play a game, not sit through a ton of cutscenes. It seems like they drop you out of gameplay to watch a cutscene between every other step. It really breaks you out of your immersion in the world.

The camera and controls are absolutely horrible. Responsiveness is sluggish and the camera is all over the place, without any rhyme or reason. The combat system is both simplistic and confusing at the same time. I have no idea how they managed that one... it's like they were TRYING to create the worst combat system imaginable.

Very linear progression. You only have ONE path to follow... no diversion. It's completely mindless. The only challenge is getting the controls to work.

I do not recommend this game. It looks pretty... hell, it looks VERY pretty. But it falls flat in nearly every other area.

reviewText:
It was very enjoyable for me to see a hot strong woman running, climbing and jumping around a futuristic city in France. The freeflow combat was fun and easy to master, with adjustable and upgradeable fighting styles. Wondrous story and ''mixing'' memories was great fun.

Very much recommended - especially when it's on sale.  :o)

reviewText:
Remember Me takes place in Paris, year 2084. In this context people has developed into a point where memories can be digitally stored and even modified, both good and bad ones. At this point of the history, some people gets full control of all those memores storage and hierarchy is still a never-ending conflict. You take control of Nilin, a young girl who lost her memories without knowing why (obviously) and wakes up into a prison cell. I won't speak more because of spoilers.

Now the pros, cons, and specially why I disagree with official reviewers.

- First of all, the mechanics of the game are simplistic and nothing innovative at all. Combat system is nothing from the other world and even though you can create your own combos the feature is not as squeezed as it could. Moreover the camera movement can become your greatest foe at some points.

However... honestly, who would care about those mechanics? Almost all new games are just a remix from others of the past. All action games are inspired by other action games, just like FPS games (which is the best example). Was someone actually looking for something new in the combat system? As long as controls are tight and responsive, I'm OK with that. And they are in this game, so just move along.

- Graphics are very beautiful. The city is astoundingly cool and I didn't expect to find this mixed aesthetics between old-fashioned, modern and cyberpunk. If you go for minor bugs, invisible walls and locked doors, you'll find plenty. But seriously, this game was crafted to follow a story, so why the hell would you enter into a clothes shop anyway?

- Soundtrack is awesome. A mix between orchestra and future music suits perfectly, and so it's demonstrated into this game. It's a very cool feature and you probably won't be disappointed with it.

- Average difficulty is insultingly easy. I've played action games on Easy mode harder than this game on the hardest settings. Chill out a bit and for your dignity just pick hard difficulty from start 'cause you won't have a trouble.

- As I said, camera can be problematic. I'm fine that during the exploration, climbing and jumping parts the camera moves for me so it focuses on where should I be looking at, but during combat and some specific times it is just killing.

- Length is OK. I've just beated the main story in about 9h, and I'll probably need another 3-5h to get all the achievements. Just the average for a story-driven game.

- The game is linear as hell. No submissions, no shortcuts, nothing. The game just drives you where it wants to, so if you're looking for a sandbox-like, look elsewhere. As for me, I'm OK when games are linear if I ALREADY KNOW they're gonna be one.

- The story is very catchy and will keep you for more. It's the main feature of the game and at least for me in wasn't disappointing in any state. It won't be the best storyline you'll play in a videogame, but it's a good one. A GOOD one.

All in all, Remember Me has been a very enjoyable experience and I wouldn't mind replaying the game. I seriously think that official reviewers can't enjoy games anymore. They just purchase them, grab their shotgun and instead of focusing on what's the purpose of a game, they simply try to find as many flaws as possible in order to make their objective" analysis. FFS

reviewText:
Meh.

That's the best I can say about Remember Me. I'm a big fan of fighting game mechanics, a big fan of melee, and a gigantic fan of cyberpunk/dystopia-themed fiction. But Remember Me is forgettable at best.

The visuals and design are fantastic, don't get me wrong, and I like the main character. What I don't like is that the city appears to be built on Total Recall (2012) logic and the only font in existance is Helvetica, as if the world had been taken over by a disgruntled, out of work hipster web designer fascist regime. Heilvetica.

The plot focuses on a society where memories are a commodity to be transferred, bought, sold and traded and uses this plot element very sparingly in gameplay - mostly a handful of sequences where you get to mess about trying to alter someone's memories. Some attacks and special powers are explained" by using the ability to transfer and alter memories as a catch all

reviewText: Linear, handholding piece of crap. Levels are just straight lines with glowing pointers . You don't even need to search secrets, they are shown to you on big golographic screens. Combat is dull and boring. It's stripped from Batman series without any innovaton. The idea of Combo Lab (constructor of your own combos) is great, but poorly implemented: you have 3 preset combo chainas and you can't change the lenght of the chain or type of moves. And btw you have just two types of moves (hand strike and leg kick), so all your combos wil look pretty identical. Also it's nerly impossible to chain combos in the large group of enemies, because switching between targets breaks your combo. The only bright side of this game is the artstyle.

reviewText:
Introduction
Whats up with ironic names in video games these days? Does developers have a challenge between themselves who can think of most ironic title for a game? Do they then have little award ceremony where the most creative dev gets awarded with a box of Jack Daniels tells acceptance speach and drink himself to the sleep? But I digress, Remember Me is a classic beat 'em up game that is set in not so distant future where everybody is sharing the memories through new technology called SenSen. I can't imagine myself sharing any of my awkward memories with anyone, but in this game it feels like memories are being shared like unflaterring pictres of you on facebook. Game starts with a commercial of different people telling about their experiences with the memory sharing technology and how it has improved their lifes to some extent. After that you see the protagonist somewhere in hospital with her memories being erased. From there you progress regaining her memories and special abilities.

The Plot
The protagonist is a memory hunter, a person, that steals and sells certain memories of certain individuals. But Nilin is special, she can also remix memories as she pleases. In the very beggining of the game, Nilin's memory is wiped and someone called Edge" helps her to escape medical facility she's in. As Nilin progress she enters a sever where she encounters her first enemies. Mindless and deformed

reviewText: An interesting story, diverse characters, a cyber-punk setting make for a fun single player game. The fluid combat that you are able to re-work on the fly by setting up your own combos from a plethora of moves is awesome. reviewText:
So I just be the game today and here's my take on it. Hope it helps for those considering to purchase this game!

Story, Art, and Characters - Simply amazing. Everything in the game has great textures and you can see the developers really focused on making sure the graphics in every scene were done carefully to ensure a complete masterpiece. The story is very interesting, as you watch the main character struggle to find her identity, struggle with morality, and the broken society. If you like philosophy, you may enjoy this game as it quotes some historic guruus.  The cutscenes are unskippable which makes replaying some levels a pain. Also this is a straightforward, single-result (meaning no different endings) type of game with no side-missions or quests.

Gameplay - Standard fights are repetitive, relying on the same button combos and limited variety of enemies. Often, I had to put the game down because the gameplay was too repetitive and not fun. However, the remixing of memories" a feature used 4-5 times in the entire game was a blast and I wish the developers made that more prominent in this game. In addition
date: it took me about 8 hours of gameplay to beat it once through without searching for hidden items or achievement hunt.\n\nIf you like a game that has beautiful art that takes "Inception" to a completely different level and that you don't mind putting down due to repetitive fighting and moving around the areas
recommended: then this should definately be a consideration to add to your library:"

reviewText:
-So empty , But yet so true , The past is a foreign country-

Well , when we talk about a game developed by a french studio then 2 things will blow your mind: the Story & the artwork.
this game isn't mirror's edge or another hack N slash game , its way different.
Its basically a new mix of martial art game , where you can mix combos of your own , light puzzle in an extraordinary style and light platforming.

basically:

-Graphics in this game is very decent and fair enough , artwork , textures , colors choice is really really awesome.
-Gameplay is way too smooth , no glitches or bugs , yet you can also create your own combos , gives you more freedom in combat.
-Soundtrack in this game is pretty much awesome , vocal choices are neat ( wish i know who was it ) , the timeing of soundtracks are well set aswell.
-Story , is mind blowing , not only full of plot twists but you will get to make the plot twists yourself !!.
-Artwork in this game is really going to catch your eyes , basically each scene of this game is full of artwork that you will have to pause and enjoy it for a few secs.
-Puzzle in this game was sort of too easy and weak , but its pretty much a whole new style of puzzle , no need to spolier you will know as soon as you play it.

generally its a must to play game , it was so enjoyable and it leaves you wishing for a Remember Me 2. <-episode 2.

i recommend this game in full price or sale price , tottaly worth it either ways. 9.5/10.

reviewText:
This is a great game, one of my favourites. From slums to the heights of society, every level is exquisite and well designed. In the nicer parts of Neo-Paris the enviroment has this polished clean look that adds to juxtaposition of the ramshackled slums and sewers. Overall graphically it is a very stunning game.

Now gameplay. There are few things to talk about here. One is combat mechanics. This game takes an interesting approach to melee Arkham like combat. It has customizable combos, which can be accessed and altered at any time through the Combos Lab. This is a really cool idea and I love the game even more for it. The second thing to talk about is the memory remix sections. This is where you remix a person's memory so that their perception of reality is shifted in one case turning enemy into ally. This is a part of the story and part of the more morally questionable aspect of the protagonist Nilin.

Lastly the story. I have to say I loved it. But then again I'm a huge fan of the Cyberpunk genre. If you don't like cyberpunk stories than you probably wont like this one. I thought is was a brilliant depication of a dystopian society masquerading as a utopia.

Last advise: If you plan to get this game use a gamepad. With these melee combo centred games I prefer to use a gamepad. It just feels better.

reviewText: I picked this one up during a sale and, man, what a deal.  EASILY worth the current $29.99 full price for the Sci-Fi fan.  I would classify this more as a Story Rich Adventure title so far.  I'm only a couple of hours in, but the Philip K. ♥♥♥♥ influence is clearly there.  It is very much like playing through a Blade Runner type movie/game and in a very good way with some new and interesting elements.  The melding of cybernetics, computers, and humanity into every day life, even in slums, is very well done and convincing.  The back story is simple enough to get you going and unfolds as you go.  For me, this is THE sleeper title of my year and I highly recommend the more casual adventure fan, particularly if they're also a sci-fi fan, pick this one up.

reviewText:
This is a beautiful game. You're playing a lot for the environment and plot. If you've missed playing combo games, perhaps you're playing it for the fighting. Once you get the hang of how to time combos, the battles become interesting and not too challenging on the normal mode.

Downsides: Learning the symbols and remembering the controls if you aren't playing in one long stretch. A bit too little explanation about how to fill in your combos in the combo lab. Not nearly enough space showcasing the fascinating memory remixing. Some of the indicators make it almost embarassingly easy to get through areas.

Upsides: Original mechanic in remixing memories, parcore like Assassin's Creed, attractive graphics, pleasant voice acting, rememberane mechanic as a story element and challenge.

All in all, I was expecting more out of this game. It was an excellent idea and there are beautiful scenes and cute 'puzzles', but a lot of times the mechanics managed one way or another to detract from my overall enjoyment of the game as opposed to providing an interesting challenge.

reviewText: When I initially saw a screenshot of this game, I thought that it would be an enjoyable experience in the same sense that Assassin's Creed was; You pick it up, play through it, and bask in the memories of having done so. It took me about a year to actually buy it, but I went into it as eager as ever. Finishing the game at about nine hours (mind you, this was on the easiest difficulty and I didn't go for all the collectables and or achievements) I can safely say that it was well worth the investment. The soundtrack to this game is fenominal and fits so perfectly into this 'Neo-Paris'. While I can't speak for the originality of a memory hunter, a protaganist with amnesia, or a rogue fighting the system, I can say that this is a fantastic RPG with a wicked story. Play this game and you'll certainly Remember It.

reviewText: Damn that was a good game. Not perfect, but a damn good game none the less. The story was incredibly good but the dialogue was laughably bad, you can tell this was made by a foreign studio (french infact). The combat can be a little annoying but it grows on you. It's basically like the Batman Arkham games but more rhythmic and less fluid. If you start a combo on one enemy, you can't continue onto another which I absolutely hated. The world, characters and artstyle were visually stunning and the memory gimmick is a fantastic concept I would love to see more of.\n\nI really loved this game and I sincerly hope to see more from the developers, Dontnod. For a new game deveoper's first attempt, this was amazing.

reviewText:
Around 8-10 hours of main storyline, this is DEFINITELY worth playing if only for the excellent storyline, strong characters and the beautiful art direction and soundtrack. This eerily convincing dystopia has elements of Deus-ex, Ghost in the Shell and Mirror's Edge at times.

Note: Recommend using a Gamepad

Pros:
- The world is stunning with a lot of care and attention to detail put into it.
- The storyline and characters are excellent.
- The soundtrack is excellent and compliments the world perfectly.


Cons
- There are QUICK TIME events on boss fights that ALMOST ruin the entire experience (They are infrequent enough to allow the rage to subside though). Whoever thought putting those in was a good idea needs a wake-up slap!
- Players of Rocksteady's Arkham games will find the combat frustrating due to a lack of counter in particular.
- The world cries out to be explorable, so it's disappointing it isn't.

The gameplay features a well paced mixture of physical puzzle solving, combat challenges and memory-remixing puzzles (one of the more interesting and thought provoking-parts of remember me) and although the sequence-based combat takes a little getting used to, it IS pretty satisfying when mastered, especially due to the dynamic music that follows the combos.

I feel critism has mainly been raised against the combat system as players have been spoiled by the (exceptionally good) combat in Rocksteady's Arkham series. However it is worth noting that the lack of counter and quick cut off when trying to continue a combo after dodging can be frustrating.
That said, Nilin, while capable of pulling off some ridiculous jumps, feels very 'human' as a result.


I also think the main reason this has received critism is that it had the potential to be so much more and so perhaps did not quite live up to the expectations of some. For example:

- The memory remixing could have had multiple outcomes in the current day depending on your choices (rather than just finding the Right" solution)
- The world is so well presented that everyone wants to explore it and interact with npcs
date: but can't.\n- WTF QUICK TIME EVENTS? SERIOUSLY?"

reviewText: Remember me has had a very mixed reception, but for me it's one of my absolute favorite games of the last generation, and easily the most underrated game of the same time period. Beautiful set pieces, a nice soundtrack, interesting original story, well realized setting, and a main character who is both powerful and vulnerable, and defies a lot of game character norms, really make it something special. The only things that the game is let down by is being extremely linear and not having the best combat system ever devised. Neither of which bothered me tremendously, especially since the combat isn't broken, it just gets repetitive. Oh, and the dialogue outside of cutscenes is a little... awful to the point of being unintentionally funny in places. But these are minor complaints with what is overall a top notch game.

reviewText:
5/10

The road to mediocre games is paved with good ideas.
It is clear that the designers wanted to create a game that was part Tomb Raider, part Arkham City, part The Matrix, and with a dash of Inception.

In Remember Me, you play as Nilin, who starts off the game with her memory wiped. Just as she is about to be sent to a jail cell, she is broken out. It is revealed that she is a memory hunter and is a key asset to help a rebel group take down a big corporation that wants to mind-control people.

The combat wants to copy the free-flow punching and kicking that was present in the Batman games, but it falls completely flat on its face. You are given set combos consisting of punches and kicks that are stronger as the combos become longer. However, longer combos are only unlocked as the game progresses. As soon as you unlock a longer combo, the shorter ones become obsolete. So you end up only repeating the one combo over and over again throughout the game.
Your combo is also interrupted if you are hit by enemy attacks or by taking too long between hits. You can dodge the very telegraphed enemy attacks, but some dodge animations are so long that your combo is stopped anyway.
There are also no AoE attacks except a few special moves that are used very rarely. As the game progresses, there are more and more enemies in any given battle, so it becomes very difficult to actually perform a combo.
This becomes very frustrating and artificially inflates the difficulty of the game.

There is significant platforming in this game. However, unlike Tomb Raider, you have arrows telling you where to jump, which defeats the purpose. It's a series of 'follow the instructions'.

The story is interesting for the middle part of the game, but becomes extremely contrived towards the end. It feels like the developers tried to put in as many plot twists as possible.

The redeeming feature of the game is the memory remixes. You are able to view the memories of some people and change small details to change the outcome of the memory. In one instance, you change a man's memory to make him think that he killed his wife, which drives him to commit suicide.

You could play this game if you have a spare 10 hours, but honestly, it's really not worth your time nor money.

Pros:
- Interesting aesthetic style
- Memory remixes - a pity that you can only do this 4 times in the game

Cons:
- Boring and frustrating combat
- Platforming is disinteresting and is used to pad out the game
- Story picks up slowly and then becomes contrived towards the end.

reviewText:
Recommended with a caveat: despite an enjoyable story, great art direction and an exciting world, there are serious flaws in the enemy design, puzzles and combat.  These are not wholly visible until suddenly they bring the game to a standstill. You are thrust into fights with enemies and combinations of enemies designed like puzzles but which are ultimately frustrating when presented to you over and over again.

Remember Me suffers from curious game design choices which leave the player confused, when simply working through menus or when he or she should be having fun. The memory remix puzzles are at first exciting, but without any clear goals and precise understanding of cause and effect, you soon realise just how prescriptive the puzzles are and thus dependant on trial and error.

So that's a huge caveat. Why then, do I recommend it? The combat can be worked through with patience. The irritating bosses and memory remixes can be solved with guides. After all that, there is a very interesting world to experience (to a point, as almost nothing is interactive unless its an enemy or game resource) and the story is memorable.

The gameplay, however, can evoke memories you might prefer to erase.

reviewText:
Short version:

Graphic: 10/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Story: 10/10
Character-Design(Story and Visual): 10/10


Its a really awesome game with an AWESOME story.

Gameplay:
Remember Me features platforming, exploration and melee combat. The game introduces the mechanic of 'memory remixing': entering and rearranging a target's memories to manipulate them. Players accomplish this by replaying a memory and modifying details to change the target's recollection of the outcome. Another key mechanic of gameplay is stealing memories from certain targets and using points called Remembranes to replay the memory in real-time: this is often needed to proceed through the game or avoid hazards otherwise hidden from the player. When the player is low on health, the screen will glitch until a sufficient amount of health is regained.

Story:
The game begins as Nilin, an Errorist imprisoned in the Bastille Fortress, is having almost all her memory wiped by Memorize. As she is taken to have the last of her memories wiped, a mysterious man called Edge, leader of the Errorists and a man she only hears over her comm device, helps her escape. Edge tells her that she is an Errorist with the gift of both stealing and remixing memories..  No spoiling :D


I got the game for ~6€, so its TOTALLY worth!
One of the best games i ever played.

reviewText:
Recall the Past
Strange. You do not know who you are. You know you are alive. But your memories are long forgotten. Thrown into unfamiliar territories and shaken by orders in the face of adversity. How do you adjust to the reality you are confronted with?  A piece missing from the shift of boxes labeled blank and new and old. Constantly triggering new emotions, reactions, and actions, and all that remains? To Remember...

DontNod developers seek to engage gamers in a unique third person action/adventure game featuring a amnesiac female struggling to regain her memories in a world of corrupted corporations and the lingering doubts that plague her consciousness. Remember Me is a fascinating third person, action, adventure, plat-forming game. Featuring Nilin, a memory hunter with the power to remix memories, subjected into a world where memories become products in the daily sci-fiish dystopian world of 2084 largely taking place in Neo-Paris. Where memories are an integral part of human society that can be tweaked, bought, corrupted, and made.

Are your memories truthful? Or filled with nuances in memory?

Jumbled, fragmented, hacked, and tweaked. Imagine any precious memory you hold dear, become erased or tweaked to suit the user willingly or unwillingly.

Keeping that train of thought we emerge with Nilin, in an ironic sort of twists starts off with having her memories erased and it is up to you to restore them and take down the corporation called Memorize because a dude compels you to. That’s it. But wait! That’s not all; enter a uniquely crafted world built by DontNod in their own depiction of Neo-Paris which I found to be strangely inviting albeit colorful in the design aspect of the game. No two places I came back to have the same environment used in the graffiti, advertisements, the paintings, slums, the vibe of the combined essence of sci-fi buildings coupled with merging it with past architecture in a sort of high tech, but with a stroke of homage to the works of old. The combination that resides from mélange (meaning mixture) creates a very awe-inspiring setting to behold. Attention to detail not only in levels and cinematic places were carefully fleshed out that for a moment I felt like I was in Neo-Paris a la 2084.So much so that I had “Woah,” “Wow,”during my blind playthrough on Hard difficulty and even moments of “meh.” These moments of “meh,” are primarily in the game-play elements...

The Wow and Meh
First off, I would like to highlight a unique aspect of Remember me in one of their game-play mechanics to go back into a person’s memory; re-live the memory through a 3rd person omniscient observer playing god. You can troll the users in the memories by tweaking it, a nudge of a folder, an open product of which was originally shut-off, or perhaps kill the client outright. It is an interesting mechanic the likes of which I can’t seem to remember a similar game like this. These moments are where the game truly shined. For not only does the memories give some insight into the story itself, it allows a great respite from the tedious combat levels.

However, the game is not just built on a point and click adventure where you can re-mix memories at your disposal. Using punches and kicks only.

While, I raise an eyebrow at such a design choice, I have mixed feelings for the brawling mechanic, not that it’s bad far from it, but it isn’t certainly exceptional in my eyes. To be frank I spent a lot of times hitting my enemies through the punch and kick style only. Through most if not all the game. My enemies were ridiculously hard. I was limited to only kicking and punching them along with 4 special abilities (60 sec cooldown’s) different from my combos. I mixed and matched my combo’s with a punch here and kick there with a combo spared in there. I felt it was tedious albeit tiresome to complete a level after a cut-scene, plat-forming a bit, walk and gawk at some artwork (Mona Lisa comes to mind) and then come back full circle against spongy enemies just to progress through the main story. I spent a lot of time mixing up my combos one’s that give health, extended combo times, and a lower cool down reduction combo’s helped tide the minor annoyance. In retrospect I think I should’ve gotten the dlc to get more combos... But... I’m a cheapskate so I didn’t think I need it. Nevertheless the game play brawling style didn’t hold a large amount annoyance to merit a negative in the game; I’m just “Meh,” on it.

Since, there were different enemies that progressed in the story that made me think of ways of how to effectively kill or shut them down made such an annoyance to a dull and mixed satisfaction when coupled with intervals of the cut-scenes to move the story along, with an interesting short cast of 10 not including the enemies. A cast of which told enough dialog to get me to become intrigued enough to be focused into the story and enough to move the story that had me guessing of how did Nilin lose her memories and why I have to take down Memorize. The soundtrack also helped keep my interest within the game throughout all of the game which was a plus in my book in adding atmosphere to each level. The boss battles too were versatile enough to not be a generic run of the mill buffed up enemy you see from around the corner. And troublesome in a good way to be different from the previous bosses and later bosses that allowed me to bear a grin on my face after countless failures most of which were my fault for being slow on the Quick time events to finally succeed.

What is Remember Me?
For Remember Me,

Is a bold new i.p.  game that quite frankly is an underrated game. Remember Me stands on a plateau with her head held high that can with time can become a truly great franchise with time and effort. It’s by far not a horrible game, and holds a certain amount of originality to its name to entice newcomers to try Remember Me and satisfy gamers with an appreciation for new Ip’s and action adventure games.

A moment of peace in a troubling world where the past can become anew, something marvelous, something enjoyable and pleasurable, beyond the scope of horrible reminders of grief or horror is that not a worthy memory to have? To buy? To Remember?

Total times beaten: 1(Hard Mode or Memory Hunter)
Legit:1
Score: 8.5/10
(Score is based off how much I enjoyed playing the game)
(Legit is based off of no cheating whatsoever, no summoning, or guides/walkthroughs/video guides)
